course.subject: MATH
course.name: Calculus II
course.description: This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the second in the MATH 1013 â€“ MATH 1014 sequence. Topics include applications of definite integral, improper integrals, vectors, curves and parametric equations, modeling with differential equations, solving simple differential equations, infinite sequences and series, power series and Taylor series.
course.prerequisites: MATH 1012 OR MATH 1013 OR MATH 1023 OR grade A- or above in MATH 1003
course.exclusions: AL Pure Mathematics; AL Applied Mathematics; MATH 1020, MATH 1024

reviews.author: Brian
reviews.title: Full of regret
reviews.comment_content: More calculus, polar coordinates, and some matrices.
reviews.comment_teaching: Skipped lectures, go read online tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
The 1014 final was on the 18th of May, 2016. It was also the day of the COMP2711 final.

Needless to say, the 18th of May was Judgement Day.

With each minute that passed in the exam hall, I could see fire rain down from the heavens and smite the poor souls, one by one. Given the conditions of the exam, it is highly unlikely that anyone would pass. I knew for a fact that I would fail. But I didn't.

Why?

There is only one possible explanation.

Ten days after the final exam and a few days before results were released, a divine tradegy occurred.

He died.
Almost noone noticed at first.
Reading the news gave me shivers.
After a while, I felt different.
My soul felt cleansed, my mind clear.
Boys and girls seemed worriless and carefree.
Everyone seemed.. purified.

He died for our sins. I will be forever grateful.

Rest in peace, our beloved savior.
reviews.comment_workload: Webwork and quizzes.

reviews.author: happystar
reviews.title: MATH 1014 - a life lesson to learn, a memorable journey
reviews.comment_content:
When a boy first entered the classroom of MATH 1014, he believed it would be a manageable course.

"I have studied M2," he thought. His heart persuaded him that online comments saying it is difficult were because they haven't taken M2.

Days after days and mid-term exam passed,
One day when I was taking the bus, I saw the canvas notification, I knew, the date of judgment came. Click it, click it, wtf it kept loading,,,, loading....loading...and my heart was gradually falling... falling... and falling.
Suddenly, the screen turned red! The Canvas red! loading finish, and the score...

38/100

I couldn't believe it, was I a rubbish? oh sorry it was not a question. I was a rubbish. And it was my destiny to fail. Thank you UST, my dearest UST, it was you that gave me such a memorable experience that I would never forget. As a finance student, getting an F is equivalent to a failure, a loser... and my dream to pursue a Finance career is just like a joke...

I need to work hard. I knew it, but given the 35% mid-term weighting, any attempt seemed to be useless. I cried, I desperated, I shouted, I laugh, I... Maybe... I was emotionally collapsed.

I heard a lot of students were shouting or complaining at the forum, but I don't even have the motivation to shout. I tired...At a night around 2am, when I was once again despressed by what my destiny was. Suddenly, an email came...

THE GRADING SYSTEM CHANGEDï¼

Mid term exam could be transferred to final! Suddenly, I smiled. I knew it was the God-given chance. I am not very bad at studying, and I knew it would be the only chance to prevent a F, which require 7 A+ if you still wish a dean list.

At that time, although it was at night full of darkness, I could feel a slight ray of hope was shinning on the sky, and waiting me to catch it.

I saw the Angel!

At the remaining time, I worked hard to fight for my grade. I knew, I really knew, that god won't give me a third chance. So the 90%-weighted final would be my only hope.

...
...
...

The exam ended, and I knew all the things gone, the toughness, the struggling, the effort... would be all become such a tiny little number, that would decide my whole destiny.

To be or not to be, that is a question.
To pass or not to pass, that decides my destiny.

At the end of the end, after clicking multiple times of canvas, my final score comes:

...

96/100

Suddenly, I was speechless. My voice was scrambling, and my eyes were staring at the screen.

Thank you MATH 1014 - you demonstrate a journey of life. From a talented M2 student to a fail student, and from a fail student to become a normal student again.

It is a simulation of a game of life

Where there is a will, there is a way...
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching was generally OK, but I eventually found that the tutorial is better than the lectures. But anyway, it depends on self-study. Professors are just here to provide you with some materials for you to learn.

reviews.author: anonymousSheep
reviews.title: It's fun!!!! not......
reviews.comment_content:
If BDSM is your thing, then you'll enjoy this. You get to learn all sorts of ways to torture yourself you didn't even know existed!!! From the light and kinky stuff like volumes of revolution to the hardcore and masochistic stuff like series expansions and partial fractions expansions.

Okay, in all seriousness, it's Calculus 2 for those who follow the US curriculum. You learn integration techniques for the first half then you go on to learning series, sequences etc in the second half. I'm sure it's useful stuff, but still hard none the less.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Extremely difficult to understand what he's saying. He has about a 1:1 ratio of filler words to actual words when "teaching". So when he teaches it goes something like this "uhh, so uhhh, today we will ummm, be talking about uhhh integration by errrr parts. To uhhhh integrate........" When I heard that on the first class, I knew that I was in for a very bad time.

Basically non-existent teaching. Instructor blitz through the content like there's no tomorrow. If you go to class, you can only hope to learn something through osmosis, because you'll be furiously taking notes that you'll never read/won't understand or you'll give up half way and just start playing with your phone or flirting with the girl next to you. Which you can then flex your intelligence and show her how much you've self learned.

To rub salt into the wound, you get NDS students who seem to understand everything to the point where they can even correct the instructor's careless mistakes. fml. If they're that good, why even go to class??
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute bullshit. You get essentially a bi-modal distribution where you have us double digit IQ locals getting 30/100 and you have the 10% of students who say that this course was a breeze and get 90+/100 for everything. Mid term and final was a bloodbath
reviews.comment_workload: The only redeeming thing about this course is the workload. The only continuous assessment that is given is the infamous webwork. However, the webwork gives you unlimited tries so you can slowly guess your way through each assesment which takes only about 1.5-2 hours each on average. Or you could Wolfram Alpha that shit and be done in 15 minutes if you don't give a damn about learning the material.

reviews.comment_content:
Integration, series, polar
è©³ç´°è«‹ç‡å…¶ä»–Poï¼Œå› çˆ²æˆ‘ä¸»è¦é»åˆ†äº«1014æ—¢è¶£äº‹

å¦å¤–é™„ä¸ŠTKLæ—¢emailï¼Œå°‡æœƒæˆçˆ²ç¶“å…¸å»ºè­°å¤§å®¶èƒŒä¸‹ï¼š
Dear Math1014 students,

A number of email starting with â€œIt is clear the overall midterm result of Math1014 â€¦â€¦â€¦â€ have reached my mailbox, but not as many as some students might have imagined; significantly less than 10 as far as I can remember. Given that about 150 students did not take the midterm exam, unlikely due to health problems, one could tell how confident some students were before the midterm day.

I do not find it necessary to argue about the level of difficulty of the midterm, and from a distribution point of view the midterm turns out to be somewhat normal; a bell-shaped instead of an L-shaped distribution. To put it on record, the past Math1014 exams before the rise of the all mighty ZOOM were all closed book exams, without calculator too.

Anyway, taking these unfortunate ZOOM days, or years, into account, Iâ€™ve unprecedentedly put a full solution of the midterm exam in the final exam information webpage. You probably should look at it and reflect on what went wrong with your own preparation for the midterm, especially if you fell apart in the midterm. Mumbling about how unfair the midterm was when compared with the past would not help a bit for passing the final. Still a few weeks of time to go before the end of the semester.

We are not here to bury students with Calculus, and there is no problem for us to switch into a max of two assessment scheme to release some pressure on students:

10%Homework + Max(35% midterm + 55% final,  90% final)  out of 100%

However, if you want a decent grade, you would have to work for it.

No assessment scheme can completely resolve the problems of those who are hit by anxiety. Donâ€™t hesitate to seek professional help from the counselors in the Counseling and Wellness Center of HKUST if necessary.

https://counsel.hkust.edu.hk/

Regards,

-TK

reviews.author: datboi
reviews.title: WORST math course for year 1 student (The review below this is lying)
reviews.comment_content:
*DO NOT TRUST THE REVIEW BELOW THIS!

This course is NOT easier than 1012/13. In fact, it is a lot more difficult. The person below who claim 1012/13 is more complicated than 1014 is lying. They are a bootlicker who has no soul.

In hindsight, the content of the course is acceptable and ok, but the exams are a different story. I feel no matter how hard you grind questions or practice, it really isn't that worth it.

Also TK also sends emails that are really passive aggressive and abusive. He gaslit students saying we didn't put effort into revising since the midterm mean was low.
reviews.comment_teaching:
meh teaching.

Hu uses a whiteboard, I am fine with this as I know alot of old people are not adept with technology. But every single time he writes something his body will obstruct the whiteboard. And then he will wipe it off in a sec.

The idiot who wrote the review below saying "student should write down their notes by themselves in order to develop a stronger conceptual understanding" is a dumbass.
You can literally just print the chapter summary from the textbook out. Its honestly so much better than copying the gibberish Hu writes on the board.

Sometimes Hu will go off topic during lectures, and start talking about unrelated math (out of the scope of this course) and a little bit of his personal life. I guess some of his personal life is a little interesting, but it often ends up to him bragging about how smart he is and shitting on high school math teachers.
reviews.comment_grading:
If you want a good grade, I advise you to avoid this course.

The comment below this is lying. They already posted their "grades" on the day the exam was held (17/05/22). They are a cunt trying to deceive you.

there is 9~10 Homework

They take a while sometimes.

reviews.comment_content:
Content is fine. One of the more positive things about this course.

Integration Techniques: Integration by Parts, Trigonometric Substitution, Partial Fractions
Numerical Approximation of Integrals
Applications of Integrals: Arc Length and Surface Area of Revolution, Average Value of Function, Work Done
Improper Integrals
Polar Coordinates: Polar Curves, Slopes and Arc Length of Polar Curves
Series and Sequences: Convergence Testing and Sums of Infinite Series, Maclaurin and Taylor Series
Vectors (Excluded in final as they ran out of time)

Some of the content might be useful in the future.

Midterms covered up to Work Done. Topics tested in the LQs are reduction formulae and solids of revolution.

LQ in the finals included solids of revolution, convergence of series, and reduction formulae (again).
reviews.comment_teaching:
If the content is the more positive thing about this course, then the teaching, and administration, are utter trainwrecks.

If we purely talk about the teaching of the course material, TK Lam actually did an OK job, despite frequent miscalculations. The most irritating thing is the attitude of the administration of this course.

After the midterm (the arrangements of which you can read from the Grading section), students complained that the grading scheme unfairly favours those who skipped the midterm. TK Lam responded by emailing us the following:
1. Saying the midterm is not particularly difficult when compared to past years, and the distribution is bell curved;
2. "Unprecedentedly" putting the midterm solutions up (shouldn't this be your responsibility anyways? "Instructors should.... Provide timely and constructive formative feedback to students on their performance as an important part of the student learning process." (Academic Registry, 2022));
3. Blaming students for not working hard; and
4. Telling us to seek professional counseling.

Apart from being unnecessarily rude and very condescending, it shows a total disregard of students who may be suffering due to insufficient MATH background. Students with C/D in 1012 might be forced to enrol in this course as it is a program requirement. Some other reviewers who quoted TKLam and wrote, "There are no excuses apart from laziness." should consider that the world does not revolve around them, and everyone's circumstances are different.

Another egregious example of administrative failure can be readily seen in the poor coordination between instructors. One instructor mentioned nearly verbatim the reduction formulae question in midterm. However, he immediately dismissed students' concerns by saying "this will not be examined in the midterm and final examination because it's too time consuming". The question appeared nearly exactly in the midterm. This highlights the failure in coordination and management of this course.

The instructor of my tutorial, Phyllis, provided useful notes and exercises. Her teaching is the only positive thing I can say about the teaching of this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
If you consider the mean of the examinations, most of the lecture sections will have mean C or D. Most famously, L2 (TK Lam's section) got a failing mean for the midterm.

The grading scheme was originally as follows:
10% Homework, 35% Midterm, 55% Final

Before the midterm, there were several threads on Goop (a social media platform targeted towards local higher ed students) about their unpreparedness for the midterm. Some anonymous people commented that they should skip the midterm if they are not prepared enough, as the midterm percentage will be automatically transferred to the final.

After the midterm, "around 150 students" (TK Lam, 2022) are found to have skipped the (more difficult) midterm. As one lecturer who wishes to remain anonymous mentioned, skipping the midterm to get a better grade should never have been an option without medical proof. How is it fair that students are allowed to skip major course grading components freely without repercussions?

After the midterm, the following appeared in the final webpage:
"No makeup exam will be arranged for minor medical reason, even with a letter form a clinical doctor. Exceptions will only be made if you are hospitalized with proof."

One can only note that TK Lam is a remarkably "compassionate" professor.

The new grading scheme, after complaints detailed in "Teaching", are as follows:
10% Homework + max(35% midterm and 55% final, and 90% final only)

A final anecdote: The instructor who gave away the midterm question previously (in the "Teaching" section) removed the 2nd grading scheme because it was "too complicated". Although this was swiftly remedied, it again highlights the incompetence in management and administration.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is moderate, as per MATH course standards.

The only workload is revision for both exams, and completing the (unlimited tries) homework.

Do get full marks in every homework, as you'll need something to save your grade after midterms and finals.

Maybe the main workload is dealing with the constant load of bullshit.

reviews.author: Un_limited_powe
reviews.title: Only a good course if u failed it once and take it in summer
reviews.comment_content:
Please be warned that this is a course review focusing on the 1014 course offered in summer semester. The spring one is absolute trash, the only reason why so many students need to retake it in summer.
Calculus II, so basically an advanced course designed to carry on the teaching in MATH 1012/1013, however, the bridging is actually very poor, resulting in basically having no idea of what's going on if you didn't do well in 1012/1013. And it is especially disadvantageous to 1012 students since they have no calculus background in high school.
reviews.comment_teaching:
It's only good cuz you do assignments in lessons, so the teachers are very willing to offer help and you actually know what problems you encounter. Unlike in spring sem where lectures are just boring and you aren't really sure what you have learnt after a lecture.
In summer basically every math tutor is here to help you so you don't fail again and probably shame HKUST in their minds.
reviews.comment_grading: Way easier to get a better grade in summer, all you have to do is to show up in lessons and tutorial and do assignments in lessons. The final exam is way easier and less stressful than the one in regular sem too.
reviews.comment_workload: As long as you show up in lessons and do assignments, you will be fine. However, do note that in summer you are finishing a 4-month lesson in a single month. You are expected to show up 3 times a week, and 5 hours per day. So if you'd like to do part time/intern, do note that summer sem courses will crash with your summer schedule.

reviews.author: averychingrocks
reviews.title: Not so easy course with on9 grading
reviews.comment_content:
- Integration techniques: fundamental theorem of calculus, substitution rules, trigonometric identities and trigonometric integrals, integration by parts, partial fractions, numerical integration, etc..
- Improper integrals: evaluation, convergence and divergence problems.
- Applications of integrals: areas, volumes by slicing and cylindrical shells, arc lengths and areas of surfaces of revolution, work done, average value of a continuous function, calculus in polar coordinates.
- Infinte sequences and series: limit of an infinite sequence, convergence and divergence an infinite series, geometric series, various convergence/divergence tests, alernating series.
- Power series: interval of convergence and radius of convergence of a power series, Taylor and Maclaurin series of functions, operations of power series, such as adding, substituting, differentiating or integration power series.
- Vectors (WAS NOT IN FINAL DUE TO CORONA SEMESTER)
reviews.comment_teaching: Honestly, I just gave thumbs up since it would be unfair to assess their grading not having gone to classes. But from the first class I attended, their accents are hard to understand and requires more brainpower. I just used to look over the content gone through in class from the notes uploaded on Canvas and learn those concepts myself through YouTube, then I would make sure I could do the questions done in the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Honestly, the grading was a bit on9.

The weightage is as follows:
Homeworks: 25%
Final Exam: 75%
**No midterm due to coronavirus

My grades:
Homeworks: 100% (unlimited attempts on classviva)
Final Exam: 95% (but only got 1q wrong - was 20mcq @ 5% each)
*my final exam copy is attached with answers but 1 question is wrong. I don't know which one lol

Overall: 96.25 (A)
**for reference, mean was 72.73 and the sd was 18.38, which is pretty high compared to historical results.
reviews.comment_workload: Honestly, this course requires constant workload since there was one homework assignment or the other almost every week. This course requires solid knowledge from MATH1012/1013 so don't forget the content, more notably integration, disk/washers method, volumes, areas and Riemann sums since they are the basis of 1014 content.

reviews.author: leon czolgosz
reviews.title: My condolences
reviews.comment_content:
Integration techniques: trigonometric substitution, integration by parts, partial fractions, numerical integration and improper integrals.
Applications of integrals: area between curves, volume, arc lengths, surface area, and work done.
Parametric equations and polar coordinates. Area.
Infinite sequences and series. Geometric series, alternating series, harmonic series, all those convergence divergence tests, power series, and Taylor and Maclaurin series.
Vectors (cancelled for final exam)

It's Calculus 2, what did you expect? I recommend Khan Academy, Organic Chemistry Tutor, Paul's online math notes and this online textbook.
https://math.libretexts.org/Bookshelves/Calculus/Book%3A_Calculus_(OpenStax)

If you're taking this course, you're probably an engineering student. You know you have two more math courses right? Good luck. (regrets life choices)

reviews.author: Gimme A+

reviews.comment_content:
Keyword Syllabus:

Review of definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Integration by parts, trigonometric integrals, trigonometric substitutions, polar coordinates and calculus, partial fractions.
Numerical integration
Improper integrals.
Area of a region between curves
Volume by the methods of slicing and cylindrical shells.

reviews.author: SQ Flyer
reviews.title: Hopefully applications more than theoretical & thinks like mathematicians
reviews.comment_content:
A continual of MATH 1013 and the Calculus Course Series for all Engineering, Mathematics, RMBI and some Science/ Business students. Focus more on applications of calculus than pure theories and theorems that only mathematicians are likely to enjoy playing with them and have such a "pure" mindset.

Topics include
Applications of integration (Area b/ curves, Volumes using Shell/Disk/Washer/Slicing Method, arc lengths, area of surface of revolution, avg. value of function, Work)

Integration Techniques (By Parts, Trigo Integral, Trigo Sub.,Partial Fractions, Numerical Integrations using 3 rules, Improper Integrals)

Polar Coordinates and Calculus (transformation, curves plotting, arc length, slope and area)

Sequences and Series (Limit Theorem, Whole Bunch of Tests, Power Series,Taylor Series and Maclaurin Series)

Vectors(Dot/Cross Product with mixed triple product)

The course focus more on applications of calculus rather than rigorous mathematical proofs and playing with pure mathematics.

The topics are in great variety and some of the topics are not actually useful for students with different intended majors and backgrounds. The whole course I think only the integrations are necessary for all students, the vectors are just for Civil/Mech/Sci students, Series mostly for EE/CE/Sci students.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching styles vary between instructors.

For LI Jun, she performed below standard. Her class is like direct copying all the stuffs from the textbook and read aloud repeatedly without further explanations, implications and conclusions.The examples shown in class are usually way too easy to understand and it's just not the exam level examples. She focus a lot on sub-topics that are actually not the key point of the chapters. And her accent,typical Mainland accent and sometimes unable to pronounce words correctly.

For TK Lam, he did a better job, just better but not the best. At least he is familiar with the topics covered in this course because he is in charge of the course for decades. However, sometimes he may cover examples which are not commonly found in the textbook and some topics are actually quite difficult to understand by just read the textbook. He addressed those parts with limited examples and not explaining in a very clear manner.Furthermore, he covers the topics in a fast manner and rush for completing all the content due to limited lecture time. And his writing... I think most of you know he writes in a messy and unorganized manner, sometimes he did mistakes and spent a lot of time searching the root of mistakes due to his terrible writing.
He is not that god-like but still just fine.

For Phyllis, the specialized IA of TK Lam, did a much better job. Her tutorial notes and exercises are useful and help students to organize and consolidate the course content well. The tutorial notes and answers are uploaded on her web-page, so everyone can directly download and finish them even if you are not in her tutorial session.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading in this semester should be absolute.

Once you did a good job than you should have no problem.

If you did something wrong, then better work harder.
reviews.comment_workload:
Just need to finish 10 Classviva assignments which are mostly not exam-type questions. The Classviva HW system is much worse than Webwork system. Always have bugs and errors for the server.

Need to work very hard to clarify the concepts and work on the mysterious questions that are not explicitly shown in the textbook and exercises. Sometimes you still need to build your "6th sense" for some questions and better figure out what sort of techniques, tricks and possibilities that are being used in different questions.

reviews.comment_grading:
Will anyone expect good grades in math courses? Unless you got 8x, 9x in exams.

    Online Homework (WeBWorK): 12%
    Midterm Exam: 33%     20th Mar (Sunday morning)
    Final Exam: 55%
    Optional MSC Bonus Quizzes: +5%

So-called "OPTIONAL" quizzes, do it, those quizzes are way more easy than mid term questions. 99% of people will get full marks on these quizzes. (Altough I fucked up one question XD)

Midterm: Above 0.5 S.D. (73/100)
the S.D. of this course started to get high, like 23 something.
Final: Above 0.2 S.D. (60/100)
Overall percentage: about 69% (74% if bonus quiz is added)
B-

Ho Hon Ming has aroused my interest in math again, he brings back my life, he gives me confidence, and he gives me the determination to strive for excellence.
Now I do practices every day and I find it fun.

reviews.author: pud
reviews.title: Ah yes, math is made out of math. Good Luck passing.
reviews.comment_content:
To be honest, the contents are not too bad. Its relatively intresting. You get to learn many techniques to calculate stuffs using calculus.

Topic wise (I will just list out the important bits.) :
- Basic calculus
- Advanced calculus ( rules,  hyperbolic, arc length)
- Fundamental therom of calculus
- Calculating Volume (A solid that rotates around an axis.) using calculus
- Polar coordinates and parametrics
- sequences series and power series
- Vectors
- Vectors in 3D and in calculus
- Partial derivatives

^ there are a few more but to be honest, these are the most important bits.

Anything before mid-terms are quite easy to learn, especially if you had previous calculus experience. I learnt A-Level Single-Mathematics and its basically an extension of the AL syllabus. However when you get to the 2nd half of the course (aka after mid-term), you better get your stuff together because polars and series are absolute HELL.

I suggest you to buy the book Calculus by J.Steward before the semester starts. You should learn in advance cause this is a very fast paced course. Literally no time to digest the contents whatsoever.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I dont know about previous year's MATH1014 structure but for this semester it is Edmund Chiang that teaches all the 1014 courses.

his teaching is terrible. dont be bothered to go to his lecture if you have the ability to learn and practice yourself.

lectures are mostly him explaining theories that gives you ZERO help when it comes to examination.

Tutorials aren't useful. Stop attending after the first 2 weeks. But it's useful if you want to ask questions.

Attendance is not a thing. So do whatever you want.
reviews.comment_grading:
mid-term is mediocre. difficulty and style are just right and very similar to sample paper that is given by the professor. Make sure to understand every question when doing the sample paper. it helps alot.

Final exam is literally the definition of "hell". so accurate that it should be written into the oxford dictionary.

Smart-looking dude sitting next to me stopped writing after 10 minutes and proceeded to scratch his head for the next 1hr 50 minutes.

I suppose that it's beacuse prof Chiang teaches all lessons and he is the only one writing the paper. It's nothing like sample paper.

In general: VERY poor grades. you should be celebrating if you passed this course in one piece.
reviews.comment_workload:
Depends.

the actual workload is WebWork. Very little questions (around 15 for every assignment.). Not difficult and you should really be aiming to take all the marks available aka 100%. This is the only chance to boost your grade. Forget about scoring top marks in exam.

however, if you really do want better grades (B or B+ above), make sure to do LOADS of practice. in the book Calculus by J.Steward, you get plenty of practice questions. Try to revise every day or at least every week. Too much to understand.

I swear if i dont have that study break before final , I shall see you all next semester.

reviews.author: Duqq
reviews.title: A terrible course which does not reward studying in my opinion (with this prof)
reviews.comment_content:
I feel very sorry for people that are required to take this course, being everyone.

Think about the smartest kid in your math class, they can get an A. I mean the kid that goes to math competitions, genuinely loves math and can spend all day thinking about math. That is what's required to get an A in this course in my opinion.

I always thought math was one of my strongest subjects until I took this course. I did a Math EE for IB and was able to consistently score 6's and 7's in HL AA Mathematics.

Despite being the course that I studied for 3x more than my other courses, it ended up being my worst grade. (B-). Don't get me wrong, it's not impossible to get an A, it's just very very very very very very very difficult.

The tutorial guy is very nice though which is a plus.
Format is Calc II material.
reviews.comment_teaching:
CHIANG, Edmund is truly an interesting teacher. If you enjoy math you will genuinely enjoy this course. However, if you simply want to get a good grade, I wish you luck.

His teaching takes a pure approach to the theories being taught in class. It is very methodical and well thought out. Except for the fact that you can't understand half of what he is saying if you do not have a strong background in proofs. Furthermore, his lectures sometimes deviate from the course material purely for his own interest. He claims "you guys must know about this, this is the most interesting modern approach to mathematics there is". Only to say at the end of the lecture that it isn't required for the course.

So anyways, I hate this professor honestly, it's simply not the way I wish to be taught Math. I skipped all lectures after he began deviating from the course material (lecture 9?) and just learned from the organic chemistry tutor on YT.
reviews.comment_grading:
Weighting:
25% midterm, 15% HW, 60% Finals

HW is easy because you have infinite attempts so not getting 100% on the HW will put you behind.

Mid-term is maybe 100% easier than the final, because the test is open-book you simply need to print out the lecture notes and it's 25% of the test for free probably?  It's still difficult though.

Final is also open book, but it won't help. Because our dear professor loves the pure side of Calc II so much that he decided to change the format of the final test. I completed all the previous past papers of MATH1014 and was able to score 80% timed. On the actual final I got 44%. Why? Because the questions being asked were not similar at all to all 3 past papers. Completely a different approach to testing students. Which in my opinion, is stupid because you should be rewarded for studying past papers? no? Maybe it's just an IB thing.

Anyways in my opinion if you get CHIANG, Edmund, you should attend every lecture and genuinely try to keep up with what he's saying, that's the best bet at getting a good grade in this course.

Except for the lectures where he teaches things that are irrelevant to the course, which you won't know until he tells you at the end of the lecture so... yeah.

ALSO:
Grading is absolute I've heard, so standard deviation whatever doesn't matter.

HW:
Mean = 75.38%

Mid-term
Mean = 48.6%

Final
Mean = 37.63%

Total:
Mean = 47.3%      SD=18.4%
Me: 57% = B-

Here is exactly how the grading works:
1.) they determine the mean after all exams are done
2.) they make the mean a high C+
3.) everything else is relatively graded based off this mean. +0.5 sd is B-, +1.0 sd is B-B+, +2SD is A range? I wouldn't know.
reviews.comment_workload:
12 HW, requiring maybe ~2.5 Hours per HW to complete, maybe less. It depends if you need to learn the content the HW requires or if you already know it, also it starts easy and gets much harder once they begin teaching sequences, infinite series, conversion, and a bunch of tests to see where series converge/diverge.

moderate - intensive. Definitely one of the courses which required the most time from the ones I took.

reviews.author: AlexBBG
reviews.comment_content: basically about integration, and series.
reviews.comment_teaching: The exam paper and the midterm are highly different form the notes he given. He asked about the definition of the laws. And the final exam are mainly about series, integration is just a small proportion. his teaching is extremely boring and it is hard to understand the concept taught by him. luckily, i have learnt integration in my HKDSE M2.
reviews.comment_grading: the grading is awful, the mean of the exam is 37/100. Even if i reached the mean, i am only C+in this course.
reviews.comment_workload: workload is fair because it doesn't contain a lot of assignment. All of  the homework are webwork.

reviews.author: mark_
reviews.title: only take in fall semester if you have a real interest in maths
reviews.comment_content:
Quite interesting for someone interested in maths.

The course becomes extremely theoretical in the second half of the semester, so be warned. If you are not used to this kind of maths, mentally prepare yourself.

Content:
- Area between curves, different methods of calculating volumes of revolution, arc lengths, surface area of revolution.
- Work done, Hooke's law, Newton's Second Law (why is this in a MATH course?)
- Integration techniques: Integration by parts, trigonometric/hyperbolic integrals and substitutions, reduction formulas.
- Polar curves (this is hard to grasp, so study ahead!), polar arc lengths/areas, polar parametrizations.
- Approximate integration (trapezium, midpoint, Simpsons')
- Improper integreals
- Sequences, convergence, test for convergence, epsilon-N definition of a limit - basically the first half of MATH1023
- Power series, Taylor series, radius of convergence
- Basic vectors (why is this in a calculus course? you don't even do any vector calculus)

The content is interesting but there are things you should definitely study ahead for. Some content is hard to grasp if you don't have great mathematical intuition. I would recommend studying up on polar curves and the epsilon-delta and epsilon-N definition of a limit.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is clearly extremely passionate about mathematics and teaching. This is especially evident when he throws in some maths trivia/history in the teaching, and also tries to show us the deeper meaning of some things.

However, he often fails to explain concepts clearly to begin with, and they only make sense if you have some surface-level understanding of the concepts. His explanations are also quite quick, so you have to pay close attention. He also makes lots of mistakes, which people often point out.


This professor is clearly passionate though, as mentioned earlier. After one lecture, I asked him a question about the complex form of the trigonometric functions and whether I could use those to my advantage in exams. After answering my question, he took me outside for a 30 minute one-to-one lecture on the history of maths and mathematicians/physicists/philosphers like Newton and Ramanujan and their contributions. It was interesting but certainly uncalled for.

The TA (Tommy) is very good according to my classmates. I agree to an extent but I found his teaching somewhat boring, but he taught some really useful manouevers which definitely helped in the exams. You should attend his tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
Webwork (homework) - 15%
Midterm exam - 25%
Final exam - 60%

For those just wanting to know what the grading is like with this prof, it's like this based on data from people around me.
Mean => C
+0.9SD => B
+2.1SD => A
(these scores are enough to get you that grade. they are not the cutoff or anything)

Stats:
Webwork - mean is somehow 80-85%????
Midterm: Mean 33.5/70, SD 17.1
Final: Mean 39.10/100, SD 18.8
Overall: Mean 48.23/100, SD 18.4
(note: the mean for the final and overall score are up to date but the updated SD has not yet been provided)

You should get full marks on the Webwork because you get unlimited attempts. Some questions are tricky though, so don't leave it to the last minute.

The midterm is moderately difficult. The main difficulty is the time limit, so try and speed through easier questions and find clever shortcuts if you can.

The final is EXTREMELY DIFFICULT. There were questions on my final that I would suspect most people cannot do. It is especially difficult for people who try and follow a rigid formula for working out similar categories of questions. For some questions, you need to be more flexible.

There was also one 3 mark question which was completely out of syllabus and could only be solved by referring to a very specific proof in the lecture notes. Oh, and I shouldn't forget to mention that proof had many bugs. The max score for the final was 97/100, so one could guess that even the top scorer could not solve that problem.

My grades:
Webwork: 100%
Midterm: 55/70
Final: 80/100

Overal: 82.64% (grade A)
reviews.comment_workload:
Extremely light.

11 WebWorks, each with a few questions. You can sit down and do these when you are bored, because you get unlimited attempts so there is no risk of losing out on points. Some are difficult though (especially homework 10) so if you do them at the last minute, you might not finish on time.

However, you should study for the midterm and finals. As mentioned, some questions are extremely difficult, and doing some problems from the textbook and sample exams will definitely help.

reviews.author: LuckyTiger
reviews.title: Petition to destroy the existence of whiteboards in zoom lectures of HKUST
reviews.comment_content:
DSE M2 : integration, applications of integrations, vectors (vectors was not in the finals for this semester)

MATH1014 : above + improper integrals, using integration to calculate work, arc length of curves, parametric curves, polar curves, area under/of/between polar curve(s) Infinite sequences, series, and representing series with functions, convergence, divergence

These are not all topics but a summary.

Disclaimer that my review may contain a lot of opinions.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This professor... uses whiteboard and broadcasts it on zoom. Professor Hu is probably the last teacher living in 2021 that still uses this method of teaching on zoom. He's right handed, and unfortunately, this professor follows the conventional way of writing from left to right. So you can imagine his writings on the whiteboard... are not visible. You can see his body though

Sometimes, I wonder if he's teaching me maths or karate cuz I feel like he shouts sometimes. But this could be interpreted as passion for some students.  

Good observation from this professor: Pretty ok summaries of some bloated topics. Always recaps stuff at the start of lesson but a lot of times verbally. Answers student's questions diligently. He provides the textbook which is pretty good in giving formulas and proofs.

Bad observations: lack of electronic adaptation, like iPad. Pronunciation is not fluent which affects explanation, mumbles near the end of his sentences a lot. Teaching is pretty textbook-oriented. I would prefer if he would use harder examples or just homework-style questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
25 percent homework
75 percent final
Since people were complaining that last year's paper was hard af, I expected it to be somewhat easier. However, it wasn't, i mean some questions were pretty similar though

I got headaches after part 1. I had a breakdown during the 5 or 10 min pause between part 1 and part 2 cuz My mind was nervous as hell cuz I got below half of the 36 pts. Part 2 came, I got slightly above half of full points which was okay but memories from Part 1 was making me dizzy. I legit started praying because I felt so hopeless. I needed to get close to full marks for this section to do just ok. God answered by prayers that day by gifting me 28/32 for part 3.

A+ 95+
A 90+
A 85+
B+ 80+
B 75+
B- 70+

I think that B- is pretty good. according to the university, it's good performance. I thought I would fail.
reviews.comment_workload: The objectives of a student in this course would be to not to fall behind or rely on friends. I managed to do both. This semester was hard personally. Regardless the workload was manageable. It's 1 HW per week but some questions were hard for me. Especially when you enroll into a course like professor Hu's you have to be diligent and adaptive if you value learning.

reviews.author: L7E2O9
reviews.title: Wolfram Alpha saves your life, fuck grading system
reviews.comment_content:
I can sum up the content as follows:
1. Review of integration
2. Applications of integration, including area between 2 curves, volume, shell method, cylindrical shell method, etc......
3. arc lengths, surface area of revolution, work
4. convergence and divergence
5. infinite sequences and series (divergence test, integral test, comparison test, ratio test and root test)
6. series of functions (Taylor series and Maclaurin series)
7. Vectors (not covered in final)

If you are interested in digging deeper in math, this course is perfect. If not, this course will screw up your GPA.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This class instructor was Professor Ku Yin Bon at first, but with no reasons Li Dong appeared to be my professor.
I attended his first class where he was late for 40 mins.........Due to his irresponsibility and his 9am session, I never attended his lesson again. The only thing I did was to download his lecture notes and self-studied.

I would say teaching is not really that important in this course once you are able to understand the concepts. Skipping lessons is totally fine.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% hw
75% final

Final exam occupies too much in this course. Final exams consist of 25 MCQs, with 9 in part a and 8 in both part b and part c.

My statistics:
Hw:
25/25, simply I reserve enough time for every hw to trial and error.

Final:
part a: 36/36 (mean: 24.29/36)
part b: 16/32 (mean: 19.62/32)
part c: 28/32 (mean: 17.73/32)

Grade: B+. Fuck Math dept grading system for not giving me an A range despite scoring higher than mean for almost 20 marks........
reviews.comment_workload:
Indeed the workload is very light, the hw in classviva is the only workload. Just to make sure you reserve enough time to do before deadline, especially for hw 9 because I attempted 56 times. If you are a deadline fighter, you will fuck up in the hw part. Therefore, reserve at least one week for the hw to make sure you get all the 25% hw mark.

Online calculators such as Wolfram Alpha and Symbolab are strongly recommended to use in both hw and final.

reviews.author: keii
reviews.title: 2020-21 Fall
reviews.comment_content:
1. Review on differentiations, integrations and Fundamental theorem of Calculus
2. Area between curves (6.1), Volumes (6.2), Volumes by cylindrical shells (6.3)
3. Work (6.4), Averages value of a function (6.5)
4. Integration by parts (7.1)
5. Trigonometric substitution (7.3), hyperbolic functions and applications, Integration by Partial fractions (7.3), Trigonometric integrals I (7.2)
6. Trigonometric integrals II, Parametrizations, Arc lengths (8.1) Area of a surface of revolution (8.2)
7.Polar coordinates (10.3), polar arc lengths and areas (10.4), Approximate integration (7.7)
8. Improper integrals (7.8), Sequences (11.1)
9. Infinite series (11.2), Integral test (11.3), Comparison test (11.4), Alternating series (11.5)
10. Absolute convergence, ratio and root tests (11.6) (18), Power series (11.8)
11.  Representation of functions as power series (11.9), Taylor and
Maclaurin series (11.10), Applications of Taylor polynomials (11.11)
12. Vectors (12.2), Dot product (12.3)
12. Cross product and applications (12.4)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Not very like his teaching, it is better to watch youtube.
He sometimes makes mistakes during the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Webworks: 15%
Mid-term: 25% (mean 60%)
Final exam: 60% (13.6/26 after regraded)

For the midterm, stupid technical issue, can't saw options for MCQ, so we extend the exam date for more than 1 week and we had the in-class exam.

For the final exam, it's horrible. Never saw any question like this before, it's just ridiculous as they are totally different from webwork, mean is about 10/26, and many of the questions were regarded several days.
He usually has several versions of announcements before the exam, and you won't know the time limit until the last minute.
reviews.comment_workload:
Acceptable workload
1 webwork every week after add/drop period

reviews.author: P.R
reviews.comment_content: Even if you have taken IB Maths HL, this course may still be difficult for you. Some of the topics are similar to the IB course, but you will learn extra stuff that was not taught in IB. However for the vectors topic, I found that this course doesn't go as in depth as the IB course. For example, the Ch 14 in the Cambridge IB Math HL book (Lines and Planes in Space) is not covered in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor has the knowledge, but he doesn't explain topics clearly. I learned most of the material by watching videos on youtube.

Attend the tutorials though, they are more useful than the lecture. The tutor I had explained the key concepts very well. The only thing though was that due to the restricted time, the tutor explains at a really fast pace.
reviews.comment_grading:
The midterm was ok. However, on part 2 where working is required, you have to write down which rule was used to deduce the limit of the sequence / whether the sequence is infinitive or not. If you do not write down the rule used, you will lose many marks.

Although final was all multiple choice, it was terrible. As everything was moved online, the professor made the questions really hard. I think the average for finals ended up being like 34 / 100.

In the end, got a C+
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fair. You get around one webwork assignment each week or every other week. Don't leave h.w last minute though, some of them can take some time.

reviews.author: Ctythomas
reviews.comment_content:
if you do not take m1 or m2, you have to work hard
if you take math 1003, no worry, you can overcome it as long as you put most of your time in this course
reviews.comment_teaching:
no need to stick with your professor, just go to the lecture you like.
Some TAs, like Phillips, are very responsible. They provide color notes which help you understand
reviews.comment_grading:
absolute grading
2 bonus quiz
sample exam papers are very useful. some questions are exactly the same.
5 marks for choosing the version of your exam
reviews.comment_workload: The most diff math course in ust

reviews.author: T. S.
reviews.comment_content:
1
Review of definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, velocity and net change, area of a region between two curves (section 6.1)
2
Volume by slicing (section 6.2), volume by cylindrical shells (section 6.3)
3
Length of curves (section 8.1), surface area (section 8.2), physical applications of integrals: mass, density and work done (section 6.4), Average value of a function (section 6.5)
4
Review of basic integrals, integration by parts (section 7.1)
5
Trigonometric integrals (section 7.2), trigonometric substitution (section 7.3)
6
Polar coordinates and calculus, areas and lengths in polar coordinate (section 10.3, 10.4) and partial fraction (section 7.4)
7
Strategy for integration (section 7.5), Numerical integration (section 7.7), improper integrals (section 7.8)
8
Mid-term Examination Mar 19 (Sunday), 2017, 10:15-11:45 Sequences (section 11.1), infinite series (section 11.2)
9
Divergence test, integral tests (section 11.3), ratio test, root test, comparison test (section 11.4, 11.6, 11.7)
10
Alternating series (section 11.5), Taylor polynomials, power series (section 11.8, 11.9)
11
Taylor series (section 11.10, 11.11), Vectors in the plane (section 12.1, 12.2)
12
Vectors in three-dimensional space (section 12.2), dot product (section 12.3)
13
Cross-product (section 12.4)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ho Hon Ming explains very clearly, teaching students step by step. Colour-printed notes are provided with tons of examples.

Zeta Chan helps us a lot on solving questions as he gives us a problem set. He shows us how to solve particular questions and guides us by coming to our seats to check our steps on calculations.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute Grading

15% Webwork
35% Midterm
50% Final
+8% 4 Bonus Quizzes
reviews.comment_workload:
Only Webwork for homework, which is pretty light.

But you must work hard before midterm and final.

reviews.comment_workload: å‰æœŸè¿˜å¯ä»¥ åæœŸæŒºå¤§çš„ midtermå’Œfinal å‰workloadå·¨å¤§

reviews.author: isdnå¥½ç©
reviews.title: You will regret taking this course
reviews.comment_content:
You will learn how to torture yourself in this course. As a student that didn't learn M2 before, it was hell for me. It was already difficult to survive in MATH 1012, my confidence was crashed by 1012. If you don't have the determination, please don't take this course. You will regret it.

If you are not familiar with integration, you will die. For me, since the MATH 1012 exam didn't include integration, I didn't study a lot of it. So I died.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I believe most of us agree that sitting lecture is a waste of time. I really don't understand why the professors couldn't explain things clearly. I know they have a lot of knowledge of math, but they just can't teach you clearly. They might be good mathematicians, but they are not good teachers.
However, a TA called Phyllis can help you. Her notes clearly explained what is happening. If you have time, try to sit her tutorials, it might be helpful (but you have to go to the classroom earlier because many people attend her tutorials)
reviews.comment_grading:
Webwork(10%)
Midterm(35%)
Final(55%)

This course claims to use an absolute grading, but even if your total mark is below 40, you still have a chance to pass this course. I think this is the only mercy of this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
It is your choice. You can have a heavy workload if you try to work hard. But the workload and results are not directly proportional.

To be honest, it really depends on your Calculus foundation. No pain no gain. The webwork is not very difficult compare to MATH 1012/1013.

reviews.author: yeetnutboi42
reviews.comment_content:
Befire midterm: integration( finding volume, area, arc length, surface area, applications like work done, solving trico integration), estimation( simpson, trapezoidal rule etc) and also polar coordinate( finding area, arc length)

After midterm: sequence, series,power series, Integration and diffentiation of power series, Taylor and Maclaurin Series

They also teach some basic vector(adding of vector, dot product and cross product) but didnt included in final exam
reviews.comment_teaching:
Didnt attended any lesson, as all resources are given on canvas, and you can access other sections's stuff (just like Math1013) so that mean you actually no need attend tutorial if other sections decided to post tutorial stuff on canvas

They would release couple test sample around two weeks earlier for revision
reviews.comment_grading:
10% by online WeBWork homework

35% by the midterm exam                             

55% by the final exam
reviews.comment_workload:
Web book only(around 15-20+ question per task, total of 10 of then)

They also would post some revision type webbk for student (optional to do, only for revision but this might released about one to two day before the test, which is kinda annoying because it contain 50+ questions and we only got 1or 2 days to finish it)

If you encounter any difficulties on hw or exam revision, just go math support center ( personally i think it is quite useful)

reviews.author: 9AmZ
reviews.title: run
reviews.comment_content: pls refer to other comments
reviews.comment_teaching:
poor course coordination

He said the â€œreduction formula" won't be tested in midterm or final, but then it accounts for almost 20 points in the midterm. So you can see the coordination was far from satisfactory.

He also taught sth not in the syllabus, so obviously, he was not well-prepared for this course, so if you were in his lecture session, run.
reviews.comment_grading:
unfair grading, students from other lecture sessions were not faked by their profs, so even the department adopted 2 grading scheme, students from his lecture session were at disadvantage because you simply cannot get a satisfactory midterm result.

For the final exam, l doubt if the department really enforced strong anti-cheating policy, coz many students were able to do relatively difficult integral in MC but were not able to solve simple integral in long q, and I did not hear any investigation about such weird situation, so really unfair grading.
reviews.comment_workload: 10 classviva homework sets, 1 was cancelled, but you certainly have to do more than these in order to get a good grade, so I wont say its light.

reviews.author: mushroomwatcher
reviews.comment_content: integration is all I can recall after the semester
reviews.comment_teaching:
After hosting a mt exam whose mean lower than 50, TKLAM wrote: (strongly recommend to recite all this cause it could be classic)
A number of email starting with â€œIt is clear the overall midterm result of Math1014 â€¦â€¦â€¦â€ have reached my mailbox, but not as many as some students might have imagined; significantly less than 10 as far as I can remember. Given that about 150 students did not take the midterm exam, unlikely due to health problems, one could tell how confident some students were before the midterm day.

I do not find it necessary to argue about the level of difficulty of the midterm, and from a distribution point of view the midterm turns out to be somewhat normal; a bell-shaped instead of an L-shaped distribution. To put it on record, the past Math1014 exams before the rise of the all mighty ZOOM were all closed book exams, without calculator too.

Anyway, taking these unfortunate ZOOM days, or years, into account, Iâ€™ve unprecedentedly put a full solution of the midterm exam in the final exam information webpage. You probably should look at it and reflect on what went wrong with your own preparation for the midterm, especially if you fell apart in the midterm. Mumbling about how unfair the midterm was when compared with the past would not help a bit for passing the final. Still a few weeks of time to go before the end of the semester.

We are not here to bury students with Calculus, and there is no problem for us to switch into a max of two assessment scheme to release some pressure on students:

10%Homework + Max(35% midterm + 55% final,  90% final)  out of 100%

However, if you want a decent grade, you would have to work for it.

No assessment scheme can completely resolve the problems of those who are hit by anxiety. Donâ€™t hesitate to seek professional help from the counselors in the Counseling and Wellness Center of HKUST if necessary.

reviews.author: wkwkwkkwkw
reviews.title: Hmm
reviews.comment_content: Integration, applications of integration, polar coordinates and series and sequences.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I stopped attending Jishan Hu's lectures because I couldn't really understand the way he explained the concepts. Moreover, he writes on a physical whiteboard and frequently covers the board with his body which made it hard to take notes.

I attended TK Lam's lectures afterwards. He teaches the concepts decently but he frequently made computation errors which slowed down the lectures at times. I actually liked him as a professor before he sent that nasty email. It's clear that the man has no respect for students and refuses to see where the teaching team went wrong on this course.

I do agree that students have the responsibility to work hard. But professors also have the responsibility to set questions that are reasonable. If the mean for the exams are extremely low, then whose fault is it actually?
reviews.comment_grading:
10% HW
35% Midterm
55% Finals

OR

10% HW
90% Finals

This course adopts the absolute grading scheme which is bullshit in my honest opinion. For a course as difficult as this, adopting a curved grading scheme is the most rational thing to do. The fact that the midterm mean was very low (3x-4x) means that almost half the class failed or are nearing a D range grade. And what if you get +2 SD above the mean? Congratulations!!! You might get a B+ or a B. Wow.

My friends from other universities said their Calculus II classes were reasonable. Simply getting above the mean will guarantee a B at the very least. And for my friends whose Calc 2 class adopts the absolute grading scheme, their professor was reasonable in setting up the exam papers and was lenient in marking.

In conclusion, this course is a shitshow.
reviews.comment_workload:
Heavy.

10 HWs (last one not counted). Each HW had around 10-15 questions and each of them had numerous sub-questions, so definitely start doing them as early as possible as it takes quite a while to finish.

Studying for the exams were definitely heavy. I spent a lot of time on this course so be prepared.

reviews.comment_content:
-more tricks for integration (trigo substitution, integration by part, by fractional parts)
-ways to get the approximation of integral (midpoint, trapezoidal, simpson's rule)
improper integral
-find volume (disk method, shell method, or simply integrate the area)
-find arc length, surface area via integration
-calculate work done
-find slope, arc length, area in polar coordinate system
-sequence & series (geometric series, harmonic series,  divergence test, integral test, comparison test, limit comparison test, alternating series test, absolute/conditional convergent, ratio test, root test)
-power series (radius of convergence, d and in of power series, estimation, Taylor and Maclaurin series)
-vector (basic operation, dot product, cross product) [excluded for exam in this semester]

reviews.author: LIFEGOOD
reviews.title: Fxcked up course
reviews.comment_content:
If you dont have so much time reading this, here is a summary. 'You are fucked if you did A-Levels and have to take this course'

I know if you went to high school in HK, you probably have already learnt many of the topics covered in this course, but if you did CIE A-levels (me), you are fucked. Everything after mid-term, you basically have to self-study from Youtube as teaching is so bad.

Before mid-term, it is not very hard to follow, but after mid-term, you are fucked. Trust me, i thought i was exceptionally good at Math until studying this course. I never had problem with math in my life but this made me hate mathematics

Alot of questions on series and sequence on finals. Finals is alottttttt (i am emphasising ) harder than HW. I did spend alot of time revising stuff after mid-term, but some of them i still do not understand.

Yeah, I know before i enroll to this course, i read reviews other ppl made on MATH 1014, i also thought i would do well if i spend enough time on this course and study on schedule, but as soon as i took my mid-term, i knew i was fucked. There were reasons why they write shit comments on this course. Uni is totally different. Acing this on top of other courses is simply impossible,  unless you learn topics  beforehand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I am sorry to Professor, but i have not seen any teacher teaching worse than him.

No attendance, and his teaching is really fast. Since its online, idk what others felt, but i could not follow his teaching, so learned every topics after mid-term from Youtube.

If there is a grade lower than F, i would rate him that.
reviews.comment_grading:
All MCQ, and since its online, he made the questions to be ridiculously difficult. It does not test you how you compute the numbers ( in other words, it does not test you which equation to use and what number to plug into calculator), but it tests you how much you understand the concept. So it is totally different from high school exams. In other words, you are fucked.

Mean overall was around 50% ish OR less

HW, you should get 100% because you can re-do until you get the correct answer.

Overall, i got higher than the mean, but only received C+.
idk if it is absolute grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
Fuck tonne. HW every week and this takes quite alot of time considering you have stuff to do from other courses as well.

Each HW has around 15~25 questions.
Well, HW is actually waste of time really because the type of questions you get on Finals is totally different from HW.
HW is all about computation, which is easy

If you find this course really hard, i suggest you give up some topics in MATH 1014 and study more on other course. This is the strategy i used and i aced the other courses.

reviews.author: smackbam
reviews.comment_content:
Review of definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Integration by parts, trigonometric integrals, trigonometric substitutions, polar coordinates and calculus, partial fractions.
Numerical integration, improper integrals.
Area of a region between curves, volume by slicing and cylindrical shells.
Length of curves, surface area, work, the average value of a function.
Sequences and infinite series, divergence and integral, ratio, root and comparison tests, alternating series.
Taylor polynomials, power series, and Taylor series.
Vectors in two and three dimensions, dot products, cross products (not tested in final exam)

Probably one of the hardest math courses to take for 1st year students, excluding honors courses of course.

Avery Ching
At this point idk if his teaching is bad or I'm just too dumb. Good that he shows proofs for every formula but the difference in level between exams and lectures/homework is just way too high. I recommend to just skip the lectures and attend the tutorials, they are way more helpful.

DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE WITH HIM.

Passing is absolute at 40% but the grading is curved with a C as the mean.

reviews.comment_content: The content is perfect, regarding the slides and the teaching notes, which is normally a strength of mainland instructors. You actually can work out the problems with course contents without attending the classes, though not recommended.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is kind of, moderate, I think? The accent is quite heavy but not hard to understand, and the class is slow and sort of dull. Questions can be solved timely and properly, but mainly not by the instructors but by the TAs.
reviews.comment_grading: Well, actually you cannot expect to have different gradings under different instructors in classes of this size. The grade is not bad generally, good work always deserves.
reviews.comment_workload: Same as grading, workload is all the same among all sections. The workload is acceptable and I think necessary for students to really get what they've learned. So never a drawback to treat homework seriously. But I do think the homework may not show exam contents well, which is kind of normal among all the fours parts that I graded. What you learn at class is NOT what you finally write on exam sheets. Good or bad? I don't know. It's up to you.

reviews.author: s~
reviews.comment_content:
Content covers Calculus II topics. Volumes and surface areas, work done, infinite series and sequences, maclaurin and Taylor seriesTechniques of integrations- integration by parts, trig substitution, partial fracrtions, average value of a function , polar coordinates, slopes and arc lengths of polar curves  and maybe-maybe nt hopefully not vectors.

Content is actually fine. It is one of the okayish aspects of the course. Midterms usually covers until work done. Series and polar coordinates are a part of finals.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Going to lectures is pretty useless. Use the tutorial notes. Use the maths support centre once in a while. LECTURES ARE SO USELESS. Organise chemistry tutor and Professor Leonard's videos on YouTube are the real deal for learning the topics. Watch professor Leonard for the topic, do webwork, few days before exams do past papers - you probably won't regret it:)

It's quite annoying when the professor says "no time today, we will cover this segment rest class" and doesn't do it. I stopped going to lectures within 2 weeks tbh. However, amongst all of them, I've heard TK Lam is the best.


I cannot emphasise this enough - watch professor Leonards videos from the start for every topic, make notes of the examples he uses. IT WILL HELP YOUR UNDERSTANDING SO MUCH. AND PAST PAPERS AFTER DOING ENOUGH CONTENT IS THE KEY TO SUCCESS. PRACTICE PRACTICE PRACTICE
reviews.comment_grading: the grading wasn't so bad. Midterm makes you feel doomed. Finals is much better. DO all your homework. Grading is descent. The only KEY WORD is practice. practice a lot. Use webworks to practice per topic after learning the content. USE past papers to understand the format of the paper and get the timing right. Pray to god they don't include vectors. PRACTICE PRACTICE PRACTICE PRACTICE PRACTICE........ Midterm is probably going to be tough by the way and it covers 35% of your grade, so doing well on midterms is essential for an A range. For a B range, you can pull up in finals.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is a lot, I mean it is Maths 1014. There are 10 homeworks but they're also good for practice. Consistency is key, don't leave stuff for last minute.

reviews.comment_content:
Syllabus:

Area between curves,Volumes by slicing and cylindrical shells,Work, average values of functions, arc lengths and area of a surface of revolution,Integration by parts, trigonometric integrals,Trigonometric substitutions, polar coordinates and calculus,Partial fractions,Numerical integration, improper integrals,Infinite sequences and series,integral test, comparison test, alternating series,Ratio and root tests, power series,Taylor and Maclaurin series,Three dimensional coordinate system and cross product
reviews.comment_teaching: An ordinary pure math teacher.He sometime made calculation mistakes.
reviews.comment_grading: Provisional grade scale:   F < 40% < D < 50% < C's < 70% < B's < 85% < A's
reviews.comment_workload: 1 Hw per week

reviews.comment_content: It uses an absolute scheme, so youâ€™d better to get prepared properly.

reviews.comment_workload: Workload(webwork) is manageable but pls donâ€™t use Chegg if you want to prepare the exams properly (ask help at the Math Support Centre instead; itâ€™s busy during the exam/hw submission period).

reviews.author: vincent.c
reviews.title: hard
reviews.comment_content:
Topics include:
applications of definite integral
improper integrals
vectors
curves and parametric equations,
modeling with differential equations
solving simple differential equation
infinite sequences and series
power series
Taylor series.
Review of definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Velocity and net change, area of a region between curves, volume by slicing and cylindrical shells.
Length of curves, surface area, and work.
Integration by parts, trigonometric integrals, trigonometric substitutions, polar coordinates and calculus, partial fractions.
Numerical integration, improper integrals.
Sequences and infinite series, divergence and integral, ratio, root and comparison tests, alternating series.
Taylor polynomials, power series and Taylor series.
Vectors in two and three dimensions, dot products, cross products.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good teacher. Explain the concept very clear.

It is a bit hard. You should master the Math 1013 first. Otherwise, it will very hard for you.

0% Worksheets (Done in tutorials)

10% WebWorks
35% by Mid-semester exam
55% by final exam
