reviews.comment_teaching: At the beginning, I do not really get what professor is saying. Just blindly copying down everything and digests the things I write in my note. For the first half of the course, it is mainly about integration which some of the contents have been taught in high school. Even though it is not that difficult compared to the second half of the course, it still needs some hard work in order to score well in mid term exam. For the second half of the course, I would say, TORTURING and SUFFERING. As an A level graduate, I have never been taught Sequence and Series. It needs a lot and a lot of practices if you want to survive through it.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is comparatively lenient compared to spring semester. For the pass or fail threshold, it goes according to absolute grading. For those who pass it, ur grade will depend on professor which I'm not sure how Ching, Avery graded this semester.

A kind advice, It is better to take this course in fall semester than in spring semester.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is considered reasonable. A weekly webwork is expected and the duration of completing it is like 1-2 weeks, depends on the difficulty of the work. Besides, there is bonus quizzes for you guys to boost the grade. REMEMBER, do the quiz as it will really help in your final grade. If you really cannot do well in quiz, at least you still collect some points and do ur best in the final, that was i have been through !

reviews.author: A random guy
reviews.title: Overall BullSH*T TA's teaching is better than the Prof (facepalm)
reviews.comment_content: Actually, the course covers some basic stuff that you have learnt in your high school (M1 and M2), new stuff including series and sequences.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Totally bad, it makes no difference if you don't attend any of the lectures. He copied everything in the notes that would be uploaded in his website, and he focuses on how to proof the theorems but in the 1000-levels, mostly students are required to solve the answer but not to prove.
In the meantime, the TA is outstanding. What she taught is completely differs from the prof. Teaching how to use theorems in practical examples and willing to answer any problems in the MSE. So would recommend you to attend the tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading: Well, the mean is 45% while if you get less than 40, you fail, so I assume that many students have a bad grade. However, the grading for students over 40% is not good at all. Although I am nearly above 1 sd, still B and but even B+, welcome to HELL for all Engineering Students.
reviews.comment_workload: Satisfactory, I would say. Just need to do 1 HW assignment in the WebWork per week and will have extra 8% comes from doing optional quizs in MSE. If you want to aim for pass or higher grade, would really recommend you to take the quizs and do all the HW.

reviews.author: cnlauad
reviews.comment_content: Mainly about Calculus and Series. Focusing more on Calculus in the first half of the semester, and then series on the following semester. No attendance would be taken may be good for those self-learner.
reviews.comment_teaching: Not as good as those reviews said, maybe Professor is good at consolidate our concepts but his lecture is quite boring.
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute with some bonus quiz, which is quite easy to get a B range because you can earn a lot of credits from those quiz
reviews.comment_workload: Just a few quiz and webwork. The workload is small and no attendance would be taken.

reviews.author: CSJJ
reviews.comment_content: Lots of modules will be taught and most of them are difficult for students to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lecturer did not explain enough, she just gives many examples and steps to solve it but it is very hard to understand if you do not know the basic.

Tutorial is better as the tutor explain detailly which is a must-attend lesson if you want to get a good grade
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute grading, it is easy to  pass as there is 8 percent bonus mark for this semester but hard to achieve a high grade
reviews.comment_workload: Webwork each week, just like the other math course the webwork allow unlimited try so it should be easy to get full marks.

reviews.author: leolee929
reviews.comment_content:
Applications of definite integrals, integration techniques, improper integrals, infinite sequences and infinite series, power series and Taylor series, and vectors.

The later parts focus less on the application but the proof. As long as you do some exercise and find the trick for proofs (which are pretty standard). It is not hard to perform well in the exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: He provides lecture videos which may be useful during your exam review. The most important thing to do is to finish the end of chapter exercise in the book which can be found online.
reviews.comment_grading: I got an A at the end. The grading was not too bad as people said. I got the full marks in tutorial attendance and webwork. It was a few marks above the mean score in midterm and around 1SD higher in the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload: Regular webwork (about 6 pieces) throughout the semester. Attendance required for the tutorial classes. Midterm and final exam.

reviews.author: cheeeaaater
reviews.comment_content: Basic Integration, Application of integration, sequence, series, convergence and divergence, Taylor series, vector ...
reviews.comment_teaching: Proof omitted. To get a better understanding of the subject, I suggest borrowing a book from the library.
reviews.comment_grading:
There will be bonus quizzes which count up to 8% of your final grade. If you perform badly in exams, don't worry you still have a chance.

Overall, the difficulty is moderate.
reviews.comment_workload: weekly webwork only. However, if you want to get a good grade, you should do the exercises provided in a website that the instructor will send to you.

reviews.author: AlanMinG
reviews.comment_content: About integration(different integration technique such as by-parts and  Trigonometry substitution), sequence and series(different types of infinite series and how to prove it is convergent or divergent), and vector(dot product and cross product)
reviews.comment_teaching: Explain concepts clearly and solve questions step by step. Provide notes with full color for students. Speak fluent and clear English, everyone can understand his teaching.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grade if you do past papers and bonus quiz.
reviews.comment_workload: Have web work every week, each assignment has 8 to 15 questions. One midterm and final. Four bonus quiz.

reviews.author: B.C.
reviews.title: Finally a math course that encourages learning
reviews.comment_content:
- Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
- Area and Volume (Disc and Shell methods)
- Integration by Parts
- Trigonometric Integration and Substitution
- Vectors, Dot and Cross Product

------ New content (DSE M2-speaking) ------
- Work (Physics)
- Average value of function
- Arc length and Surface
- Polar coordinates, Polar Arc length and Surface (Parametric Equations)
- Partial fraction and its integration
- Numerical methods (Approximate Integration)

- Sequence and Series
- Series Tests
- Alternating series
- Power series
- Taylor and Maclaurin Series

- Set definition of planes, intersection of planes (slightly mentioned only)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Li Zhen is a new professor, teaching for his first time.

- Merit: Passionate and actively listening. His lecture style is just to use the whiteboard for everything, very wonderful as we can follow how he thinks. His presentation skills in terms of delivering the content is spectacular, everything just links together as lecture approaches the end: you can see him trying to show a theorem many times with various examples as if until you are convinced. Feel free to keep him after lecture for questions and you would see him solving them with you. (Handwritten notes available later online)

- Weakness: His English accent is not particularly good but understandable. His pace of going through concepts and examples in a lecture can be quick and even accelerating, but it is equally satisfying if you manage to follow such a pace; there is often a 5 minute break in the middle :)


Zeta Chan, our tutorial TA, is very practical in solving questions. More like exam-oriented style problem-solving, which is interesting because Prof. Li put it theoretically and you may yet see how you can apply things. A big thumbs-up for his tutorial question set: he stapled and prepared a collection of all-topic questions across the whole semester, just bring that over every time and go to the question he is doing now (answers in a file was released online later). Questions are also highly welcomed; he would walk to you to confirm if you did it right, either by asking or looking at your writing. His English carries the Hong Kong-er accent but you can tell despite this he lays out things intuitively.


TA support in the Math Support Center is sufficient but usually poorly delivered. I don't feel welcomed, but rather kind of a trouble asking obvious questions. Maybe the TAs are already annoyed with meticulous queries of simple questions, and they are systematic enough to put up solutions onto the whiteboard just letting us to refer to it. But regardless of how much we learnt, this is not a learning environment that encourages trying, at least to me.
reviews.comment_grading:
15% Webwork - basically full mark for everyone
35% Midterm
50% Final
* +8% Quiz bonus (4 quizzes each 2%) - special policy in my semester because our (all students taking math 1014 this semester) midterm results are too horrible in general

Absolute grading:
- Overall 85% -> A-range hence A-
- (Seems Overall 90% -> A)
- (Seems Overall 95% -> A+)
So the quiz bonus is really a lenient policy. In my case I was just off A-range and got an B+, but because of the quiz results I got two sub-grade up to obtain an A in the end
reviews.comment_workload:
Webwork: treat it as a concept revision, look up the concept after you try to do it yourself, then it won't seem difficult; do it early so that you can seek help when you figured out you need

Midterm and Final: definitely attempt the sample paper given, because often the format is similar. Tutorial exercises are recommended as revision materials before final, because merely understanding would not be enough. You can even get tutorial exercises from other tutorial sessions, for example I used: Einstein's https://sites.google.com/site/einsteinkongstutorialwebsite/

(Quiz: in this semester we have the quizzes starting from Easter break. 4 quizzes split into two periods to take, two quizzes available each period.
There were sample questions available for you to exercise with for as much time as you wish, and frankly the format is again very similar to the real quizzes.
Recommended to take them all early because as the deadline approaches the Math Support Center would be full-house but you must take the quiz with the computers there not yours; the quiz also has a time limit of 15-25 mins, so taking it with fewer people around shall relieve stress if any)

For math lovers or curious people: I made notes solely on equations/concepts on my own and did the in-lecture/tutorial examples together with the lecturer/TA. So in my humble opinion, paying more attention during lecture and tutorial plus some little reinforcements at times would save much time. It is both more rewarding and efficient.

a bit more difficult than math1013

applications of definite integral, improper integrals, vectors, curves and parametric equations, infinite sequences and series, power series and Taylor series.

difficulty of topics related to applications of definite integral are similar as math1013
vectors are basic m2 stuff (cross, dot product and some applications)
topics related to sequences and series are more difficult

very clear explanation in every example (including every important step) and may use some creative examples to explain some concepts

absolute grading

final: 50%
bonus quiz (because midterm result is not satisfactory among all math1014 students -- mean is about 5X/100 for midterm)

as it's absolute grading, won't be affected by those crazy guys (those almost got full mark in midterm and final), finally got A reange
reviews.comment_workload:
just webwork (about one deadline per week while no. of questions vary)

questions related to application of definite integral and vectors are easy but questions related to sequences and series are more difficult

reviews.comment_content:
Second part of MATH1013 which I think is (of course) harder than 1013.
---
Definite and Improper Integral
Vectors (High School level, make sure that you get all questions correct for the vectors part in the exams)
Curves and Parametric Equations
Trigonometry Integration
----
!!! Harder Parts: !!!
Power Series
Taylor's Series
Infinite Sequence
----
Useful content for engineering students but might be a bit boring for students who are into statistics and probabilities.
reviews.comment_teaching: Personally, i think that Ho Hon Ming is the best Math prof in HKUST. He explains in a clear tone and slow but sure. He always hands out this color printed note every lecture, so make sure that you always attend the lecture on time because some students from other lectures would come in just to take the notes. He gave us more example exercises online which greatly helped me to study for the midterm. He also posted his lecture videos online, so don't worry about getting late or skipping morning lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
15% Webwork
35% Midterm
50% Final
---
BONUS ! 8% Quizzes (3x)
make sure you get all the no. correct, these quizzes can boost your range from a C to B- real quick. Or B- to B+ etc.
---
They used absolute grading back then so I got like minus 1 below mean for both my final and midterm bus still got B-, Quizzes did them magic.
reviews.comment_workload: Same like other math courses, webwork once a week. 10 webwork(s) in total and they count like 10-15% of the total score. Don't expect that the questions would be similar to the webworks.

reviews.comment_content: The contents might be basic calculus, which is useful in later studies.

reviews.author: smiling
reviews.title: Strongly recommend the MATH 1014 lecture taught by Dr HO, Hon Ming
reviews.comment_content:
Around 30-40% content are taught in M2 syllabus.

1) Applications of Integration
- Areas between two curves*
- Volume by slicing (Disk Method)*
- Volume by cylindrical shells (Shell Method)
- Length of curves
- Area of a surface of revolution
- Physical applications (mass, density, work done)

2) Integration Techniques
- Basic integrals*
- Integration by parts*
- Trigonometric Integrals*
- Trigonometric Substitution*
- Method of partial fractions
- Numerical Integration
- Improper integrals

3) Polar Coordinates
- Polar coordinate system
- Areas in polar coordinate system
- Arc length in polar coordinate system

4) Infinite sequences and series
- Sequences
- Infinite series
- Divergence test & integral test
- p-series
- Ratio, root & comparison test
- Limit comparison test
- Alternating series test
- Absolute convergence of infinite series
- Taylor polynomials & Taylor series
- Power series

5) Vectors*
- Three-dimensional coordinate system*
- Dot product*
- Cross product*

Content above put with asterisk are in M2 syllabus.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr Ho teaches by 3 screens. He writes down what he says while teaching, so you must know what he is talking about and you can follow the progress. He will repeat the important point once. The notes written in the lecture actually come from the the notes you got, but you should still attend his lecture, you will understand it better. At the end of each lectures, he will ask all students whether they have questions, I have never seen that there was students raising questions at that moment. However, if you really have questions, you can and you should ask him after the lectures. He is willing to answer you. You will feel his solemn attitude in the lecture and I also noticed his smile once only in the lecture (same as one of the previous reviewer). However, you will notice his sincere smile more if you ask him questions sincerely.

Two reminders :
You need to attend his lectures to get the lecture notes. There are lecture videos on Canvas.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scale : absolute grading
A+/A/A- >= 85% > B+/B/B- >= 70% > C+/C/C- >= 50% > D >= 40% > F

Grading scheme :
15% by Online homework assignment (Webwork)
35% by Mid-term exam
50% by Final exam
+8% by 4 additional Online Bonus Quizzes

Mid-term mean : 52.09   SD : 15.54
Final mean : 67.34   SD : 15.29
Total mean (excluding bonus quizzes) : 66.77   SD : 11.59

One thing to highlight is that the final mean is higher than the mid-term mean, this implies that the difficulty of the final is even lower than that of the mid-term! The final exam is indeed easier in this semester.

My results :
Assignment full marks
Mid-term : 59 (above 0.44 SD)
Final : 87 (above 1.29 SD)
Bonus quizzes : 96.07% (+7.69%)
Overall (including bonus quizzes) : 86.84%
Got A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Main workload is the online homework (Webwork). Better to finish the relevant questions after the that content was taught. If you want to get a better result in the exams, you should review the lecture notes on the day that being taught. Don't accumulate these little workloads until the exams, you will be overwhelmed by the thick lecture notes. I
suggest finishing some tutorial exercises.

reviews.author: Alpha703
reviews.title: Sad
reviews.comment_content:
1. Integration(Integration techniques, arc length, volume, surface area, physical applications, indefinite and definite integrations, improper integrals, integration in polar coordinates...)
2. Sequences and infinite series(Convergence of sequences, infinite sums, convergence/divergence tests on infinite series, power series, taylor polynomials, taylor series...)
3. Vectors(All M2 stuffs)

Not a lot of DSE M2 things. Topics in sequences and series are quite hard, please study hard on it and don't be like me.
reviews.comment_teaching:
(Note: I am not enrolled into Dr. Ho's section but I sit his lessons for the whole semester)
His teaching is super clear though a bit fast, and he explain the examples/concepts very thoroughly. His colored notes are very useful in revision.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading. Grade cut-offs are almost the same as Math1013, but since the contents are much harder, the grading is harsher than Math1013.

Midterm(35%) Mean: 51.17/100 SD: 22 Me: 56
Final(50%) Mean: 64.03/100 SD: 25.05 Me: 67
Webwork(15%) You should get full marks on them, but I don't since I missed one of the deadlines and only have 90% and have a lower subgrade. Fml.
Bonus Quiz(+8%) Me: 85/100

Total: 73.4/100 -->B-
The cutoff between B- and B is 74.6.
reviews.comment_workload:
Webwork: Similar workload as Math1013. Since the contents are more difficult and not all of them can be Googled, the workload can be higher. DON"T FORGET TO DO ANY ONE OF THEM OR YOU CAN LOSE A SUBGRADE LIKE ME.

Exams: Depends on your expectations on the grades. Honestly I studied for 2-3 days before the exams only. If you want to aim for A range, WORK HARD and good luck.

Lecture: No attendance required. But don't dare to skip lessons unless you have access to lecture videos.

reviews.author: calcguy
reviews.comment_content: The content may be a bit too much for some students, because it covers about 5 chapters in total
reviews.comment_teaching: Well explained. The lecture notes he provided before each lecture are really useful for our learning.
reviews.comment_grading:
For the first time in a while, Dr. Lam (course coordinator) sets an absolute grading scheme instead of relative grading, but the grading may be bad for a majority of students (about C range). Quite beneficial for people really good at this course.

P.S: Better not showing off my scores here or I will be hated so much
reviews.comment_workload: We do not need too much time dealing with webworks (if you attend the lecture seriously), but that itself is not sufficient for learning. Gotta have to do lots of revisions to be able to get good results.

reviews.author: MS01
reviews.comment_content:
The course uses the same textbook for MATH 1013.

Chapter 6: Section 6.1 - 6.5 (Applications of Integration);  Chapter 8: Section 8.1 - 8.2 (Arc length and Surface Area)
Chapter 7: Section 7.1 - 7.8 (Integration Techniques, including improper integrals);  
Chapter 10: Section 10.3 - 10.4 (Polar coordinates and calculus)
Chapter 11: Section 11.1 - 11.11 (Infinite sequences and series, power series)
Chapter 12: Section 12.1 - 12.4 (Vectors, dot product, cross product)

The integration and vector part are just the same as the M2 calculus in HKDSE. The most difficult part should be the infinite sequences and series because there are many concepts and theorem involved. Therefore, I spent most of the time in studying this part.
reviews.comment_teaching:
His notes are well prepared and clearly explained the equation, however, you have to attend his lecture in order to get his notes because there are no electronic copies in canvas. There are also lecture videos provided.

Revision exercises will also be uploaded in the canvas and they are quite similar with the midterm and final exam. So, it is better to study them as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading for this semester:
15% Webwork
35% Midterm
50% Final
+8% bonus quiz (optional), 4 bonus quizzes in total

I was slightly below mean in the midterm exam, and above 0.5 SD in the final exam. Webwork and the bonus quizzes are100% correct. Finally got a B.
reviews.comment_workload: The only workload is the webwork. There are 10 webworks in this semester. It is recommended to do the exercise in the textbook in order to familiar the concept in each topic.

reviews.author: ransacker69
reviews.title: A course which tests your concepts and understanding of mathematics
reviews.comment_content: Calculus based content with a little bit of basic vectors at the end.A lot of practice is required and there are many concepts to learn. Understanding the concepts is very important so an aptitude for math is required.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is decent, but the course is more about self study and grasping various concepts. Can approach support centre to clear any doubts related to course content.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is strict. Mid Term mean was 34 out of 100. Final Examination mean was 31 out of 100. If you're at mean overall, you can expect to get a C+ at best. I ended up getting a B- as I was above mean throughout, but not by a very large margin. Clearly not a course that would boost your GPA.
Overall percentage grade breakup was as follows:
Mid Term-30%
Final-50%
Quizzes(combined, 5 in total)-10%
Webwork(combined, 11 in total)-10%
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is high. One mid term, final exam, 5 quizzes that you have to go to the math support centre to take, and 11 webwork homeworks. Basically, something is pending all the time. Tools like Wolfram Alpha can be used to solve webwork questions but you can actually learn valuable stuff and stay up to date in terms of syllabus if you actually study to solve the webwork questions as a new homework pops up as just about every topic is completed.

Passing mark was 20%

30% for mid term
50% final

Fairly easy, in the webwork format.

Around mean, C+. It's very hard to get good grades.

It is the difficulty of the content and the bad grade that makes this course one of the worse engineering compulsory MATH course in year 1.
reviews.comment_workload:
10 webwork in total
4 bonus quiz
Similar to 1013
Not too much in my opinion.

reviews.author: Mickey
reviews.comment_content: His ppt slides are very clear and almost cover all the details. The content is a bit easy and what he taught is just the example on the ppt slides.
reviews.comment_teaching: When he is explaining the examples, he says very specific and tell the students the key point. And additional examples he won't waste more time and just let students to review after the course.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade is better than normal but if you want to achieve A+, it is still difficult. You need to be extraordinary.
reviews.comment_workload: One homework per two weeks with 10 problems. The problems are basic and easy so the workload is ok.

reviews.author: Gman
reviews.comment_content:
Application of Integration(area ,volume,arc length,surface area,)
Integration techniques (by part ,trigonometric substition, partial fraction, numerical integration)
Improper integrals
Sequence and series
Power series and Taylor series
Vectors
It starts easy in the beginning but gets quite difficult towards to end.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching method is very elaborative and clearly shows his way of tackling a problem with his thinking methodology and the steps that follow. All of this is accompanied by his own personalized notes that are also very detailed with plenty of examples to go through for each topic.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grade Distribution:
WebWork = 12%
Mid term = 33%
Finals = 40%
Bonus Quiz x 4 = +5%

It's a 'bonus quiz' and you have a choice not to do it, but since every one does it, its basically a part of your grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Rather heavy.
There's one webwork due almost every week with around 8-20 questions with a total of 10 webworks in the entire semester.
The midterms consists of slightly easier topics where as the final exam is quite difficult as you'll be tested on all of the content, so needless to say, a lot of self-practice is required to avoid getting things mixed up.

reviews.author: CatJin
reviews.comment_content: Content was interesting - just further covering about integrals and its application.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is very good at explaining the concept and allow us to understand them very well. Sometimes he is really funny (unintentionally).
reviews.comment_grading: Grading so bad and very high SD. I worked so hard but bad grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Not too much workload I guess since there is only midterm, final and online assignment. Even though during the semester you may feel there aren't much to do, there are so many things to study for the midterm and final.

reviews.comment_content:
advanced math1013 more about sequence and testing whether it is infinite or not, actually not that difficult(it is important to understand all Webwork)
A lot of test for them, confusing me at the beginning(better to be able distinguish them as soon as possible, don't keep mixing them up in study break)
reviews.comment_teaching: Nice instructor, attractive hair style ^_^  , if you(a local) find him after class for asking questions, he will explain it in Cantonese, gd gd

reviews.author: wwongad
reviews.title: Better than 1013
reviews.comment_content:
What the course covered:
1. Integration technique,
included : Direct integration, substitution method, trigonometric integration and substitution, partial fraction, integration by parts, application of integration

2. Sequences and Series
3. Introduction to 3D vectors

The hard part for me is about sequences and series. So better be careful on that part
reviews.comment_teaching:
I like Dr. Ho's teaching as he prepared his own colored notes and his handwriting is very nice and tidy. But for me the pace of his lectures were quite slow as he sometimes explained the things explained before.

The tutorials themselves were useful as the tutor gave us many review questions that can be used to prepare for the exam
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite bad. The marking scheme for exams was quite harsh. Little mistakes could lose you half of the total marks for that question.

12% WebWork
Easy to get full marks because there were no limits to answer those questions

33% Midterm
Mean 61.23/100
SD 23.37
There are quite a lot of students who got perfect score I think

55% Final
Mean 55.73/100
SD 20.93
The final exam itself was much harder than the midterm
reviews.comment_workload: The only workload for this course is the WebWork every week.

reviews.author: SL
reviews.comment_content:
The contents are integration, vectors, approxiamtions etc.
It is easy at the begining and become quite difficult afterwards. The content in the midterm and  final is much more difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: HO Hon Ming teaching is quite good as he list the steps and thinking procedures clearly in his lecture notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
grading distribution:
WebWork 12%
Midterm 33%
Final 45%
Bonus Quiz +5%

It is quite difficult for you to obtain high grade or even b range. The mean is at around C+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite high
One WebWork once a week around 8-20 questions.
Midterm exam are mostly easier topics and some have been covered in the HKDSE M2 syllabus.
Final exam you have study around thirty something lecture notes

reviews.comment_content:

Integration technique (by part ,trigonometric substition, partial fraction, numerical integration)
Improper integral

Power series and talyor series

reviews.comment_teaching:
HO HON MING is quite good with his teaching and well elaborate of the concept. The worst thing is that you need to attend in class in order to get his notes.
Einstein is a good ta. He explain the qestion very well and provide us many exercise.

reviews.author: HKG_SIGMA
reviews.title: Needless to say.....
reviews.comment_content: Basically, this course is a sequel of MATH1013. Containing more in-depth calculus, it is surely harder to handle. The scope is quite broad in my opinion, covering more difficult integration techniques, sequence, convergence and divergence, Taylor & Maclaurin Series, vector manipulation...I think it is way more than what a 3-credit course is expected to introduce.
reviews.comment_teaching: Daniel's teaching is not bad anyway. Perhaps it is because of the venue (LT-C), if you are late for the lecture, you gotta sit at the back and prepare for not being able to see any contents from the whiteboard. The Prof's delivery could be often tedious that provokes you to leave early.
reviews.comment_grading:
Extremely poor grade as always. Mean for MT is 6X/100. Tons of my friends got grades below mean. Some of them even got 3X and 4X. It is foreseeable that the grade for Final would be catastrophic. Obviously, that's the consequence of containing too much content.

For me,
MT: 75/100 (~0.58 S.D. above mean)
Final: 59/100 (Just around mean)
I did not get full marks in most of the bonus quizzes(got around 50-60% in each quiz except the first one) so I am not sure about how much extra point I gained.
Ended up with an B-. Way better than my expectation, for such a killing MATH course.
reviews.comment_workload:
As you may count...
WebWork (weekly)
MT
Final
4 optional Bonus Quizzes at MSC (at maximum extra 5% towards your final grade)

reviews.author: bacbac
reviews.title: Repetitive Material
reviews.comment_content: Mostly repeating what students have learnt in senior high school. Though it may seems useful, it only scratch the surface of materials and will not be that useful for the higher level courses.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very boring teaching style. Though he gives a lot of examples.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is similar with other math courses.
If your total score is :
1. Mean, will be around B- range
2. Mean + 1 SD will be around B+/A- range
3. Mean + 1.3++ SD around A range
4. Mean + 1.7++ SD around A+ range

However, with healthy mean of around 50, getting ++88 for the final score will guarantee A+

Furthermore during that time, they have bonus quiz that can counts up to 3% of your total score.
reviews.comment_workload: Besides having 1 midterm and 1 final, you only need to finish webwork that keeps updated for every 1/ 2 weeks which will only take a small portion of your week.

reviews.author: Felix ZHANG
reviews.comment_content: Covers basic skills and knowledge for further study. But there are no proofs for some conclusion.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good elaborations and detailed notes. The notes are really useful. The instructor is also very responsible and patient. But the way he gave his lecture is a little boring.
reviews.comment_grading: Normal grading. Neither bad nor good. Work enough and you will make it.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not so great. But you still need to do excess practice to get the satisfactory grade. Math is just understanding and practice. Generally, the webwork is not enough. The tutorial is somehow useful.

reviews.author: nibbles360
reviews.comment_content: Extremely difficult course with a lot of topics covered
reviews.comment_teaching:
course was well taught and explained by the instructor.  Dr HO makes the topics somewhat understandable.  Coloured notes are provided which have plenty of examples with explanations.

Tutorials were useful
reviews.comment_grading:
surprised I even passed this course, got 22% in the mid term, don't remember what I got in the final but probably a really low mark, still ended up with a C-.  

There are bonus quizzes which boost your grade by up to 3%.
reviews.comment_workload: Average workload with assignments due every week or so on webwork.

reviews.author: SVM
reviews.title: Difficult course
reviews.comment_content: This course is called one of the most difficult courses in HKUST and I agree. The content, till the midterm, is difficult but manageable. However, after the midterm, the content slowly and steadily becomes so incredibly tough that by the time the finals are around the corner, the syllabus looks like Mt. Everest.
reviews.comment_teaching: Ho Hon Ming is a good professor, who is very systematic and his notes are easily the best notes available. In fact, if the content would have been easier, I think anyone can understand the concepts by attending his classes.
reviews.comment_grading: Difficult exams+Bad grading. Worst combo ever.
reviews.comment_workload: Took a lot of help to complete the webworks. There are optional quizzes to get bonus points. I was an idiot to never go for them. I strongly recommend others to take the quizzes.

reviews.author: alejandro
reviews.comment_content:
integration
polar coordinates
improper integrals
vectors
series and Taylor series
much harder than DSE M2 materials
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher spoke too quickly and it was hard to catch up.  Sometimes he got confused and taught wrong stuffs.  He gave many examples.  Can just go to MSC to ask the staff when you encounter problems.
reviews.comment_grading: Not too good grade
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was not too heavy. Online webwork homework + midterm + final.  Can go to MSC to ask for help on webwork assignments.  The midterm and final consisted of about 20 MC questions and 3 to 4 LQs.

reviews.author: GK
reviews.title: More than M2, less than what a 3 credit course should do
reviews.comment_content:
This course continue from the MATH1013, starting with integration. The method of integration is mostly the same as of HKDSE M2. However, partial fraction was not included in my DSE education, which is included in this course. (But some other students said that this was taught also in M2)
The application of integration is more difficult than HKDSE M2. After that, sequence and series are also being taught. This might be quite difficult for M2 students so don't think this course is as easy as MATH1013. The content can be said to be less than  what a 3 credit course should be, but it is not as simple as MATH1013.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Chow is more like a tutor than a lecturer. Though he would talk about some theory, but he will be more based on applications and examples. The lecture notes are excellent and his class is better than Ho Hon Ming. Don't understand why he is less popular but I think it is quite fun to attend his class.
Dave Au is an excellent tutor. He would try his best to answer student's question.
reviews.comment_grading:
This course is a standard bad grade course. The mean is somewhere on C+ (?). I got 9X in final with above mean 1 SD at midterm, resulting in A only. Very pissed off.
But I think it is quite good in terms of the super low work load
reviews.comment_workload: Super low if you have M2 basic. All you need to do is to do easy webwork and self study for exams. Most part of the course can be ignored if you have M2 base. Take this course as a vacation course!

reviews.author: AAA
reviews.comment_content:
It is part II of single-variable calculus.  The difficultiy is moderate.
Topics include applications of definite integral, improper integrals, vectors, solving simple differential equations, infinite sequences and series, power series and Taylor series.
reviews.comment_teaching: Poor teaching method and style.  I simply skip all the lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
In order to get good grade, all concepts should be fully digested and completely understood, especially series and estimate errors.
Above 1.4 sd in both midterm and final as well as full mark in bonus quiz which is optional, I got A
reviews.comment_workload: Only webwork with unlimited attempt.

reviews.author: MathGod
reviews.title: Difficulty is similar to MATH1024
reviews.comment_content:
1. Integration I (Basic concept)
-The definition of definite integration
-Inequality/rule used in integration(e.g Mean Value Theorem, Triangle inequalty, Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, etc)
-Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
-The definition of indefinite integration
2. Integration II(Integration techniques)
-Integration by substitution
-Integration by part
-Partial fraction
-Integration involving Trigonometry Functions
-improper integral(Comparison test, limit comparison test)
3. Geometry
-Vector(Dot product, Cross product)
-Parametric equation and Parametric curve
-Arc Length, Volume and surface area
-Polar coordinate
4. Sequence
-Definition of sequence and infinite sequence
- Squeeze Theorem and Order Rule
-Monotone Convergence Theorem
-Rigorous Definition of Sequence limit)
5. Infinite series
-Definition of infinite series
-Series vs improper integration
-Basic Convergence Tests
-Absolute and Conditional Convergence
-Power series
6. Taylor Series and Fourier series
-Polynomial Approximation
-Taylor Polynomials
-Taylor series
-Fourier series
-Further properties of Fourier series
reviews.comment_teaching: I come from L1 section, which us different from other section, it started from the basic of integration, so the the teaching speed of ivan ip is incredibly fast, but I think he is the best math professor so far, since he really discussed all of the remarks for some concepts, like fundamental theorem of calculus(FTC), not only he discussed some special cases for FTC in order to make the concept clearer, he also raised some counter examples for reference. Also, he is patient and pleasure to answer questions from students after the lecture, and the most important thing is he sometimes say some jokes during the lectures, the atmosphere of lecture is good.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is very losse for L1 section, for mid term, the mean id 41.55, sd is 16.212, the highest score is 88, and the lowest score is 14, the distribution is very jaw dropping, and for final exam, it is very simliar to mid term, the mean is 40.94, sd is 19.53, the highest score is 92, the lowest score is 5.

I got 53 in both mid term and final exam, got a B+, I think it is normal, since I know my ability is still not enough, I think it is a miracle to get a B+ in L1 section, since the content of mid term and final exam are really hard.(All courses taught by ivan ip are usually hard to get a beautiful exam aiiii, and I heard from my friend that the mean of mid term and final of a math course taught by ivan ip haven't exceed 45, since ivan ip loves asking some counter example, which is never taught in class, and you need a lot of time to think)
reviews.comment_workload: workload is not much, each week had a one hand-written homework to submit, but the questions asked in homework are sometimes easy and extremely hard, but the grading is very loosen(I think)

reviews.author: KrazyKaren
reviews.title: Math Mayhem
reviews.comment_content:
Keyword Syllabus:
â€¢ Review of definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  
â€¢ Integration  by  parts,  trigonometric  integrals,  trigonometric  substitutions,  polar  coordinates  and  calculus, partial fractions.
â€¢ Numerical integration, improper integrals.
â€¢ Area of a region between curves, volume by slicing and cylindrical shells.
â€¢ Length of curves, surface area, work, average value of a function.   
â€¢ Sequences and infinite series, divergence and integral, ratio, root and comparison tests, alternating series.
â€¢ Taylor polynomials, power series and Taylor series.
â€¢ Vectors in two and three dimensions, dot products, cross products.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Due to my decision to not attend lectures, I am unable to provide a personal evaluation of this specific lecturer. However, I can share that the course materials are provided in the form of handwritten notes and in-lecture notes, which allows for self-learning.

Additionally, attending Phyllis Liang's tutorial sessions is highly recommended. Her tutorial notes are of high quality and serve as excellent practice material. Reviewing her tutorial notes before attempting past year papers can be more efficient than going through all the lecture notes. It's worth noting that her tutorial sessions tend to fill up quickly, so it's advisable to arrive early to secure a seat.
reviews.comment_grading:
The difficulty ranking for the course components is as follows:
1. Lectures: Considered the least challenging aspect of the course.
2. Homework: Slightly more difficult than lectures, a bit useless I would say.
3. Tutorials: Some tutorial questions are taken from homework and past year papers, making them moderately challenging.
4. Past papers: More challenging than tutorials as they provide a comprehensive review of the course material.
5. Actual Exam: The most difficult component as it covers the entire course and requires comprehensive understanding.

It's important to note that since the grading is absolute, your performance in the course will solely depend on your understanding and preparation.
Letter grades will be assigned depending on overall performance. The following is the rough guideline: A+/A/A- > 85.5 > B+/B/B- >70.5 > C+/C/C- > 50.5 > D > 40

Homework (WebWork) 10%
Midterm Examination 35%
Final Examination 55%
reviews.comment_workload: The workload in MATH1014 is slightly higher compared to MATH1013, but it remains manageable. There is an assignment that you have to hand in every week and it also allows infinite retries so it is recommended to get a 100% for this.

reviews.author: mi0304
reviews.comment_content:
Following from MATH1013 L01, MATH1014 L01 covers 6 chapters:
Chapter 5 Integration I - Basics
Chapter 6 Integration II - Techniques
Chapter 7 Geometry
Chapter 8 Sequences
Chapter 9 Infinite Series
Chapter 10 Taylor Series and Fourier Series
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures: Prof. IP taught in a good way that it was easy for students to catch up, and he is willing to answer questions. You can skip any lecture as he provided helpful recordings. The attendance was not recorded.

Tutorial: This is very helpful. The tutor was friendly and he responded to your questions in time.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% - Assignment (Full mark for each hw is 60, 10 times overall, abandon one of the lowest mark)
10-40% - Midterm (Automatically weighed at the end of the semester)
40-70% - Final

The professor published this on canvas at the beginning of the semester:
"Letter grades will be assigned depending on overall performance.
Obtaining a total point of 95% or above will guarantee an A+.
Obtaining a total point of 80% or above will guarantee an A-range.
Obtaining a total point of 60% or above will guarantee a B-range.
Obtaining a total point of 30% or above will guarantee a passing grade."
But he did not really follow this, because no one got that high. Finally, people who got over 80% got A+, over 72% was A, over 65% was A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignment: No webwork but one written homework every week. This is much easier than MATH1024 and MATH1023, but I think it would be harder than WebWork.

The midterm only covered less than two chapters, which was manageable, but the final covered more. But fortunately, professor decided to not test too much on Geometry and Fourier Series, only some true/false questions included those contents. If you passed MATH1023, the content covered after midterm would not be that difficult, since lots of stuff were repetitive.

reviews.author: Mubin
reviews.comment_content:
L01 section is harder than other L02-11 sections and easier than MATH 1024 and it is specifically designed for potential Math Majors. While the main content is similar to other sections, L01 section emphasizes conceptual understanding and will have a lot of proof writings.
If you enroll in other sections, you may find it harder to transit into second-year math courses, especially MATH 2033 - Mathematical Analysis, which is a required course for Math majors, and it requires a strong logical mindset and solid conceptual understanding of single-variable calculus.


(Note that, unlike other sections, L01 section starts from the beginning of integration.)

Integration: Riemann Integrations, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Integration Techniques, Reduction Formula, Improper Integrals.
Geometry: Vectors, Parametric Equation, Polar Coordinates, Volume.
Sequence and Infinite series: Convergence Tests, Power series, Taylor Series, Fourier Series.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Ivan's teaching pace is always like watching a video at 1.5x speed. To grasp all the content, it's better to study the lecture notes before attending the lectures. It will also be great if you watch the recording of the lecture again after attending the lecture in person.
reviews.comment_workload:
You have to solve a lot of problems. You have to dedicate a lot of time to that. Solve ALL the problems of Calculus, Early Transcendentals on Classviva. Make sure you keep in mind the different type of problems available there. Some of them will be trivial, harder problems will come in handy. Make sure you solve the Exercise problems of Lecture Notes, Worksheet Problems and go through the tutorial notes.

Finally, DO NOT be a deadline fighter!

reviews.author: IDIOTHAHAHA
reviews.title: Useful content but trash lecturer trash TA
reviews.comment_content: The content are super difficult but the lecturer always skip some critical concepts and assume that you know them.
reviews.comment_teaching:
After seeing some people said Ye Guibo was a decent lecturer, I enrolled in her session. However, I found that her lectures notes are very messy and hard to read because every page is full of words.

Besides, I think I found some mistakes in her lecture notes so I sent email to ask all 3 TAs of L9 because Ye Guibo said she never answer email on Sunday and Saturday. Still no one reply my email after one week. What would you feel when you spend a lot of time on setting query and composing emails but the receiver ignore them. I don't really care whether they are strong or not but I care about their attitude. But I guess one male TA of L9 is decent and acceptible because he tried hard to answer my questions in tutorial class T9A. Although I might not fully understand some concepts, I still appreciate his efforts.

Also, Ye Guibo's accent is bad. For example, in last few lectures I finally figure out that "offer-we-are-say" is "obviously". So pay attention to it.

Another thing is that she doesn't want to run the risk of being late on another class so she would only answer you very briefly if you ask her questions right after class in that situation.

In tutorial class, most people just attend the first one to see whether the TA are good or not and whether attendance would be taken or not. After that, there can be no one in the classroom except the TA and you (if you attend).
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 35%
Final: 55%
HW: 10%
because many people in the below review said that the grading is bad, I guess it will probably remain bad so I give a E. This is an induction, right?
reviews.comment_workload:
9 compulsory homework on webwork. Since you can try unlimited times, you would eventually do them all correct unless you don't have enough time.
You also need to spend a lot of time to digest the lecture notes because as I say, Ye Guibo's lecture notes are actually bad.

reviews.comment_content: cal
reviews.comment_teaching:
It's very challenging to comprehend what he's saying. When "teaching," he uses filler words in a ratio of around 1:1 with actual words. As a result, when he instructs, it goes like this "So, today, ummm, we're going to speak about, err, integration by parts. In order to integrate," I knew I was in for a very awful time when I heard that in the first class.

basically no teaching at all. The instructor moves quickly through the material. If you attend class, your only chance of learning anything is by osmosis since you'll be frantically scribbling notes that you won't ever read or comprehend or you'll give up midway through and just start fidgeting with your phone or making small talk with the girl sitting next to you.

reviews.author: _Wh.M
reviews.comment_content:
The content includes:
1. Integration (by part)
2. Volume (disk method, shell method)
3. Work Done
4. Plane Coordinate (arc length, surface area)
5. Polar Coordinate (length, area)
----- midterm exam -----
6. Numerical Integration (Trapezium, Mid-point, Simpson)
7. Improper Integration
8. Sequence and series*
(convergence, epsilon-delta, integral test, limit convergent test, root test, alternating series test)
9. Power Series and Taylor Series* (radius of convergence, Maclaurin expansion)
(the most difficult topic I think)
10. Vectors (dot product, cross product,

The topics with * are important topics (tested a lot in the final exam)

The content is really difficult. The syllabus of DSE M2 only covers a very small part (by part, disk method) of the content of this course. Some of the topics like Reimann sum in MATH 1013 can be seen in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think TA is helpful and the in-class exercise helped me to build a better understanding on the content being taught in the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Tutorial in-class worksheets (20%)
Midterm Exam (25%)
Final Exam (55%)

My mark:
tutorial in-class worksheets - missed four tutorials
Strongly recommend to attend all the tutorials. Get the easy marks and solidify your understanding.

midterm - 75/80
(mean: 37.4 sd: 19.51)

final - 60/100
(mean: 30.02 sd: 15.09)

The midterm exam is okay, but the final exam is terribly difficult.

Final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Except the midterm and final exam, we have to finish a in-class worksheet once a week in the tutorial session. There is a total of 12 tutorial classworks, and the professor will drop the three worksheets with the lowest marks.

We are asked to do at least two questions on the worksheets to obtain full marks. The TA will give full marks even though the answer is not correct or incomplete.

I think the workload is ok, but I am too lazy to attend the tutorials, so I would give a C.

reviews.author: oscargu
reviews.comment_content:
Topics include applications of definite integral, improper integrals, vectors, curves and parametric equations, modeling with differential equations, solving simple differential equations, infinite sequences and series, power series and Taylor series.

For the integrals, its like more on the high school stuff.
For the curves, the course will teach you to calculate the length and area etc.
Some concepts and usage of the series will also be included.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is not really good. Pace is a bit slow and the spoken English could be more fluent, or else it may affect the learning.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading
75% Final
25% Assignment

No mid-term

The online assignment is basically once per topic (1-2 weeks)
You can submit unlimited times until you are satisfied with your score (try get full score on each assignment, it will be helpful)
Read the notes and keep the concepts clear is ok, also you can do some exercise or review the questions in assignments if you have time.

Assignment (100%)
Final (92%)
Grade: A
(Overall grade >= 95% can get A+, what a pity)
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not high, just one assignment per 1-2 weeks. Each assignment contains 8-15 questions, including MC and short questions.
Other than that, you may need study harder near final.

reviews.author: ç¥ä»™1è™Ÿ
reviews.title: Youtube videos helped me a lot.
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1

Review of definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. (4.2, 4.3)

Week 2

Substitution Method (4.4) Integrating by parts (4.5)

Week 3

Trigonometric integrals, and the method of partial fractions (4.6)

Week 4

Numerical integration (4.7) Improper integrals (4.8)

Week 5

Areas between curves (5.1) Volumes by slicing (5.2)

Week 6

Volume by cylindrical shells (5.2) Arc lengths and surface areas (5.3, 5.4)

Week 7

Polar coordinates and calculus (5.5) Work (5.7)

Week 8

Infinite sequences and series (6.1, 6.2) Integral test (6.3)

Week 9

Comparison tests (6.4) Alternating series (6.5)

Week 10

Absolute and conditional convergence (6.5) Taylor and Maclaurin series (7.1, 7.2) Representation of functions as power series (7.2)

Week 11

Interval of convergence of a power series (7.3) Applications of Taylor polynomials (7.4)

Week 12

Three dimensional coordinate systems, Vectors

Week 13

Dot product, Cross product
reviews.comment_teaching:
I had only attended the first lecture in the whole semester because I found watching youtube videos were more efficient for me to learn. I suggest The Organic Chemistry Tutor because he explained the concept well with various examples. Despite the fact that he don't explain how the formulae come, I find it is enough for me to get a mark close to the mean.

If I had learnt how the formulae are derived, I would have had more understanding on those topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
I don't know why other students said the grading of this course is good. If you get a mean mark, you may get a C+.

The exam is not hard because it contains all mc questions. Not figuring out an answer, you can choose one of the choices. If you are lucky enough, you may get all correct although you don't know what exactly the answers are.

Remember to read through the instructions of the exam, which will be sent to you via email.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not heavy. There is around 1 assignment per week on Classviva website . Just finish the assignments and you will get a basic understanding on those topics.

I got some help from the UST Maths centre. I found it was quite useful when I got stuck in a question for a long time and could not find the answers to the questions on the internet.

Past midterm paper and final paper will be uploaded to a website which you can find it in the email from the instructor when the exam is approaching.

reviews.author: line
reviews.title: Calculus II
reviews.comment_content:
Velocity and net change, area of a region between curves, volume by slicing and cylindrical shells.
â€¢ Length of curves, surface area, and work.
â€¢ Integration by parts, trigonometric integrals, trigonometric substitutions, polar coordinates and calculus,
partial fractions.
â€¢ Numerical integration, improper integrals.
â€¢ Sequences and infinite series, divergence and integral, ratio, root and comparison tests, alternating series.
â€¢ Taylor polynomials, power series and Taylor series.
â€¢ Vectors in two and three dimensions, dot products, cross products.

If you study M2 in HKDSE, congratulations, you have finish  over 75% of the course. The only thing left for you is Series and sequence

EXAM: midterm, 10 MC, 2 long question; final exam, online 20 MC

Textbook: J. Stewart, â€œCalculusâ€ , no comment

If you got problems, go to Math Support Centre (MSC), very useful and helpful

reviews.comment_content:

Overall, it is a quite interesting course. It also teaches the calculation involving rotation of volume and area which I think is the most difficult part.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Lam teaches really detailed for this course. He will also talk about some in-depth application and out-sy things. But generally, he has passion to teach this course and I have learnt a lot.

The only bad thing is that his class is on 9am. It is so tired to wake up early in the morning for a MATH course.

It turns out I got an A grade but not A+. A little bit angry about this just for 1 question wrong in final exam.

The only workload of this course just have a weekly homework to do. And the deadline is few weeks later.
So that there is more than enough time to do.

Integration Technique like by-part, Trigo, etc
Area and volume, surface area and curved distance
work done

Series and sequence, like Taylor series
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is passionate in teaching since he frequently asked students questions and answered questions patiently.
He also prepared extra quizzes and materials for us to revise and hold extra sessions for students to revise some previous concept even the one in math1013, which benefits some students who is from math1003 like me.
He replied email very fast even in hours b4 final.
reviews.comment_grading: This sem is ok since no midterms, only one final with only 20 mc questions. I know ppl get A+ with all correct. I got 19 questions correct and the grade is A.
reviews.comment_workload: So many webworks and the questions are a little bit challenging, so I need to go maths center to ask. Some students will do extra practices in textbooks.

reviews.title: Support Li Weiping & Phyllis
reviews.comment_content:
Harder content than Math1013.
Four main parts:
- technique of integration
- application of integration
- sequence & series
- power series (Taylor series)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Really good professors & TAs, both of them can explain most of the content clearly (well, most but not all, some of them are very unclear, but at least they are far above the standards of other professors or TAs in this course. Don't expect too much for math professors)

Li Weiping is very passionate and willing to answer students' questions detailly after lessons.

Phyllis, without doubt, prepared the most wonderful Math calculus notes for us. The notes are very detailed and include most of the examples you need to remember.

So, remember to sit their lesson!!!
The content of the course is quite hard so recommend to really attend lessons/ watch lecture videos

reviews.author: solarbear
reviews.comment_content:
Cover everything basic in calculus, especially integration to different scenarios. Take the course only to suffer from death.

In fact, the course is so damn confusing and difficult for anyone who is not that into maths. It covers things that are fundamental. But ask you things that requires your deep understanding.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is boring and useless. Go to tutorial to learn examples directly is better.
reviews.comment_grading:
Although the course is hard, the grading is decent as the mean is so damn low. Around 40-60 if I remember.

Not be so worried if you got a relatively low result, cause everyone is also low in this course.

Got fifty sth in MT, 80 in final, about 3/4 in bouns quizzes, comes out a B.

Just remember it is normal to get a bad result in this course, don't get frustrated is the only thing important to get a better grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is low, only WebWorks and optional bonus quizzes after MT. The workload can be high if you dig deep into the knowledge and strive for a A grade.

Tutorials don't count attendance, so you can skip all the classes for this course if you are confident enough.

reviews.author: ç§‘å¤§å¼•æ“ä»”
reviews.title: Easy af
reviews.comment_content:
Integration techniques
Integration by parts, substitution , parital
Polar coordinate

If BDSM is your thing, then you'll enjoy this. You get to learn all sorts of ways to torture yourself you didn't even know existed!!! From the light and kinky stuff like volumes of revolution to the hardcore and masochistic stuff like series expansions and partial fractions expansions.

Okay, in all seriousness, it's Calculus 2 for those who follow the US curriculum. You learn integration techniques for the first half then you go on to learning series, sequences etc in the second half. I'm sure it's useful stuff, but still hard none the less.

A lot of things need to study

Chapter 6: Section 6.1 - 6.5 (Applications of Integration);   Chapter 8: Section 8.1 - 8.2 (Arc length and Surface Area)

Chapter 7: Section 7.1 - 7.8 (Integration Techniques, including improper integrals);  

Chapter 10: Section 10.3 - 10.4 (Polar coordinates and calculus)

reviews.comment_content:
- Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
- integration techniques
- polar coordinates
- vectors
- series
- sequences
reviews.comment_teaching:
- mainland professor
- difficult to understand
- better to study yourself
- study materials are provided
- I skipped, sorry :(

reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading.
Better do all webwork as the midterm and exam are hard.
Better to do the bonus quiz, they will give you extra marks.

Base on your ability.

reviews.author: Jorge
reviews.comment_content: Useful content but is a bit too difficult for students who have not yet been familiar with calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is a little boring but he is clear when articulating the calculations and the Powerpoints. The tutor Justin is quite a funny person but his writing is a bit messy.
reviews.comment_grading: I find it not hard to get a good grade as long as you put sufficient effort into the webwork and ensure that you understand how to do each question.
reviews.comment_workload: Basically comprises webwork only. There is no attendance taking in his lessons.

reviews.author: Rexllll
reviews.title: Not as bad as they say
reviews.comment_content:
This course mainly focuses on 5 major topics
1. Integration
2. Polar Coordinate
3. Approximation of Integration
4. Infinite Series and Sequences
5. Vector
This course will not be too difficult if you have studied M2 in DSE. The vector part of this course is no where near as hard as that in DSE. Nonetheless, I would suggest you to put some of your time in understanding the theory behind infinite series and sequences, as it is more important than doing tons of practice.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I cannot comment on the teaching of the professor since I have only attended her lecture twice. Nevertheless, I do have to say that her notes are amazingly clear. I have been going through the whole course only with her note, the course reference book and the tutor.

Personally I find my tutor most helpful. My tutor is T06C, I am sorry but I can't find his name. He did I very great job at explaining difficult concepts and providing challenging questions if you wish to do them.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute Grading.
As long as you get higher than 85% you get A range. It doesn't matter if the rest of the class is higher than you are not.
reviews.comment_workload: Not a lot.The assignments given can be dealt with within 30 mins. There will be quizzes which adds to your final score. Remember to try the example questions before doing the quiz, as they are 80% identical. Get full marks in all the quizzes, then A+ is within your grasp.

reviews.author: YANG Yihan
reviews.title: Better than 1013
reviews.comment_content:
integral based on 1013
for sure,much more difficult than 1013
never try to learn by yourself, or you have to spend more time on it
reviews.comment_teaching:
her english is quite ... never expect too much on math depart.
the speed is quite good in her lectures, fast in the first half sem and slow down in the second half sem
her lecture notes is good. you can study the course on yourself by IT but try not to do so as I said...
she will also provide a practice website
reviews.comment_grading:
better than 1013
try your best to take the bonus quiz, which is definitely the best part of the course!
the 8%bonus quizes will be of great help to you final grade
the midterm and final were easier than I expected coz I really got into trouble with the hw (try to review the practices and the hws)
you can also turn to math support centre for help although it was crowded somtimes some tutors are strict while some are quite nice
reviews.comment_workload:
if you attend all the lectures and pay full attention during the 90mins, the workload is ok. only the 10 hw, 4 quizes
if you skip the lectures, even just some part of the lecture, you are a dead man. spend another 3 hrs for the 90mins lecture!

btw, all I said is suitable for just normal people.not those who are talented in math><

reviews.author: fl19o
reviews.comment_content: Just calculus. More difficult than MATH1003 but still very manageable.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is neat in notes and explains ideas and concepts well in class. But sometimes he taught slowly, which is good for the difficult concepts but not much desirable in simple things. He provides quite a lot of examples to solve in class to help you learn better.
reviews.comment_grading:
The sample paper is extremely helpful in the final and midterm exams because the questions are similar.
Absolute grading, which is really nice.
15% webwork + 35% midterm + 50% final
can have at most 8% bonus if you take the bonus quizzes.
Overall 85 is A-.
About 90-93 is A ( I don't know the exact number)
reviews.comment_workload:
During the semester, the workload is only in lecture and webwork. You may have to refer to notes or review a bit before doing the webwork but most of the time it's fine. Plus that you can always have Wolfram Alpha to help xd.
Before exams you have to review more and do the sample paper so more time is needed.
But overall the workload is quite light.

reviews.author: _cyl_
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1: Monday (Feb 5)
Review of definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
Area between curves (6.1)
Volumes (6.2)
Week 2: Monday (Feb 12)
Volumes by cylindrical shells (6.3)
Work (6.4)
Average value of a function (6.5)
Week 3: Wednesday (Feb 21)  
Arc length (8.1)
Area of a surface of revolution (8.2)
Week 4: Monday (Feb 26)
Integration by parts (7.1)
Trigonometric integrals (7.2)
Week 5: Monday (Mar 5)
Trigonometric substitution (7.3)
Polar coordinates and calculus (10.3, 10.4)
Week 6: Monday (Mar 12)
Partial fractions (7.4)
Strategy for integration (7.5)
Week 7: Monday (Mar 19)
Approximation integration (7.7)
Improper integrals (7.8)
Midterm Exam: Mar 25  (Sunday 10:15-11:45)
Week 8: Monday (Mar 26)
Sequences (11.1)
Infinite series (11.2)
Integral test (11.3)
Mid Term Break: Mar 30 - Apr 5
Week 9: Monday (Apr 9)
Comparison tests (11.4)
Alternating series (11.5)
Absolute convergence, ratio and root tests (11.6)
Week 10: Monday (Apr 16)
Testing series (11.7)
Power series (11.8)
Representation of functions as power series (11.9)
Week 11: Monday (Apr 23)
Taylor and Maclaurin series (11.10)
Applications of Taylor polynomials (11.11)
Three dimensional coordinate systems (12.1)
Vectors (12.2)
Week 12-13: Monday (Apr 30)
Dot product (12.3)
Cross product (12.4)
reviews.comment_teaching: Didn't attend tutorial at all, attend a few lectures. Not very useful, can understand everything by reading lecture notes yourself. Doing exercises are more important than attending lectures.
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute grading, 15% Webwork+35% mid-term+50% final exam + 8% bonus quiz, 85% or above scores A range. Even if you score only around 30% in mid-term and final exam, you can get a D at least, not easy to fail if you attend all quiz and webwork.
reviews.comment_workload: Only Webwork, very very light workload.

reviews.author: Kit9973
reviews.comment_content: This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the second in the MATH 1013 â€“ MATH 1014 sequence. Topics include applications of definite integral, improper integrals, vectors, curves and parametric equations, modeling with differential equations, solving simple differential equations, infinite sequences and series, power series and Taylor series.
reviews.comment_teaching: ok la I did not attend all the lesson, but I think his explain is enough clear.
reviews.comment_grading:
As usual, about a quarter of students did not perform up to a minimum standard in this midterm. Like last spring, four MSC bonus quizzes will be set up later for those who would like to catch up with some hard work in the next five weeks or so. Up to a maximum of additional 8% maybe earned for those who work through
those quizzes. By TK lam
It is difficult to get F as webwork and bonus quiz give you 23%...

for me overall 103% and get A+.
and 97% above for A+ and 90% above for A.
this year, the final is similar to sample paper and very easy, and many people leave early...
reviews.comment_workload: Like Math1013, you need to do webwork and have unlimited trials. You also can seek some help in MSC. So I think this course is not too heavy.

reviews.author: ustiong
reviews.comment_content:
about integration:
- applications: area, arc length, volume , surface area, work done, polar coordinates and calculus
- techniques: integration by parts, reduction formula, trigonometric substitution, partial fractions
- Approximating integrals: mid-point rule, trapezoidal rule, Simpson's rule
- Improper integral: test for convergence, comparison theorem

Series:
- limit of infinite sequence
- sum of infinite series
- basic example of series: geometric, harmonic series, p-series
- tests for convergence: divergent test, integral test, comparison test, limit comparison test, ratio & root test, alternating series test
- Power series, Taylor and Maclaurin Series

Vectors:
just some basic things that you've learnt in M2 such as dot product, cross product, triple scalar product, orthogonal projection and volume of parallelepiped
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Jin used his own iPad Pro to prepare and show the notes in colors which help us to understand the graph and the rotation etc.
But from my view point, I still not fully understand the topic even though he use a lot of examples in the class.
For the tutorial part, the tutor may be to fast to move into the example s, but after the mid-term he would like to brief the equation and the teaching content first. It helped me to refresh my memory
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading. The scales and the % in mid-term, final exam and others can be refereed to others.
But I think some students' grade were adjusted a little
Me: mid term and final exam scores were below the mean; bonus quiz are not in full mark; webwork problem sets were all done...Still have c-
reviews.comment_workload:
Need more extra effort and exercises may be better; webwork questions are really not enough

sample paper is useful and try to do it by yourself is better

reviews.author: chpoonag
reviews.comment_content:
- knowledge in Math 1013
- volume (shell method and disc method)
- work (physics)
- average value of a function, arc length, area of a surface of revolution
- integration by parts, trigonometric integrals, trigonometric substitution
- polar coordinates and calculus
- partial fraction
- approximation integration, improper integrals
- infinite sequences and series, integral test, comparison test, alternating test, absolute convergence, ratio and root tests
- power series, representation of functions as power series, Taylor and Maclaurin series, application of Taylor polynomials
- 2 and 3 dimensional coordinate systems, vectors, dot and cross product

In the final exam, the main focus is on the series and sequence. Requirements of and conclusion given by each test (for convergence or divergence of a series, eg Comparison Test, Alt. Series Test, ...) should be RECITED clearly. It is also reminded that if requirements of a test are not completely satisfied, usually no conclusion can be drawn.

There is a distinct teaching and exam style for those lectures taught by Dr Hu Jishan. His exam and test are different from others in that they focus on proofs whereas others focus on application matters.

It could be a great advantage if you took M2 in college.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr Yang's teaching a fair. His voice is without intonation, which could make you fall asleep. He follows what is taught in the textbook, page by page. It may be a good thing as he would then never go off-topic. You may ask him questions whatever you have come up with just after the lecture.

Mr Fan is a patient and responsive TA, despite few students' attendance of tutorial class. You can ask him after tutorial class, or by email. There was once just some hours before the exam that he replied to my email only 6 minutes after the email was sent to him.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading.
15% homework
35% midterm
50% final
+ 8% bonus quizzes (4 in total)

Note: F < 40% < D < 50% < C-/+ < 65% < B-/+ < 85% < A-/+

Long questions in the exam paper is pretty akin to the sample paper (ie the paper of previous year)

~My performance~
Homework: 15/15
Midterm: 90/100 (4 marks gained after paper checking)
Final: 97/100
Grade: A+

**Always check paper and asked for any possible marks for correct methods.
reviews.comment_workload:
Small workload. A total of 10 WeBWork assignments, usually 1 per week or a bit longer than a week, contingent on the progress of teaching. You have unlimited times of attempts for each questions.

Like the previous year, due to too high percentage of students getting F (40%) in the midterm, 4 bonus quizzes which accounts for a total of an EXTRA 8% in the final total score would be done in maths support centre. It is reminded that sample paper will be provided in the maths support centre without answers, but you can ask the tutors there if you wish. Those sample papers are really helpful as they were derived from the actual papers we did and hence they were very similar to the actual ones.

reviews.comment_teaching: I don't know because I've skipped all the lectures, just read the book and online materials only.
reviews.comment_grading:
15% Webwork: full unless you forget to do it
35% midterm: moderately hard, it covers the applications and techniques of integration
50% final: hard but the questions are very similar to the sample paper
*8% bonus quizzes (2% each): you can get full if you do the sample questions

A provisional grade scale:
F < 40% < D < 50% < C-/+ < 65% < B-/+ < 85% < A-/+
reviews.comment_workload: light workload. You only need to do webwork every week. Some integration and vector stuff are taught in M2 but the new content is slightly difficult especially the series. It may take some time for you to understand the new content.

reviews.author: Trafalgar Law
reviews.title: Fair course
reviews.comment_content:
Integration and series I would say...
Basically a lot of in depth integration techniques that you have to keep on practicing. Series are quite easy as you just need to understand it and read more examples.
The content is not that difficult for me personally (although the mid-term is very difficult and bloodbath for everyone), but it depends on your dedication (time spent) on it, as well as your mathematical background (e.g. Math 1013 or HKDSE m2)
Add oil la
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor generally is nice person who is here to answer the questions. His teaching is acceptable (at least understand what he teaches, but boring). I guess he is from Mainland...
reviews.comment_grading:
absolute grading, seems like 90%A, 80%B, etc, and then +-5% is plus and minus. But this semester (17-18 spring) they come up with a super easy final paper and then the A+ is moved up to 97%, damn. Didn't got A+ even though I get >95% in the final...
I'd say the grading is quite fair as I screw the mid-term (~70%lol, be prepared, it is super hard). But there are 8% bonus quiz, that's how you take your grade back.
Final 50%
Midterm 35%
HW 15%
Bonus quiz 8%
reviews.comment_workload:
Not much... But MUST JOT DOWN DATE OF HW!!!!!!! I missed one of the HW!!!! I hate how the system do not display all the 10 homework deadline at once, but release one by one when time passes.
MARK DOWN THE DEADLINE OF NEXT HW EVERY TIME YOU'VE DONE HW!!!!!!!

( The vector is not included in the final)

Homework 10%
midterm 35%
final 55%

reviews.comment_workload: The workload is 9 homeworks , same as 1013.

reviews.author: Christian_Chow
reviews.title: I like this course
reviews.comment_content:
Everything in MATH 1013 + Integration + application of integration (volume, area, work, surface area, polar curve length/area etc) + ways to approximate an integration

improper integrals + infinite sequences and series + power series, Taylor series and Maclaurin series

not much actually

This is a easy course honestly with enough hours spent in this course

B-

acceptable workload
